edges.c: Sea anemones are a group of predatory marine invertebrates belonging to the order Actiniaria. They are named after the Anemone, a terrestrial flowering plant, due to their colorful appearance. Sea anemones are classified in the phylum Cnidaria, class Anthozoa, subclass Hexacorallia. They are related to corals, jellyfish, tube-dwelling anemones, and Hydra.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sea anemones have a single polyp attached to a hard surface by its base, with a columnar trunk topped by an oral disc with a ring of tentacles and a central mouth. The tentacles are armed with stinging cells called cnidocytes and are used for catching prey. Some species have a symbiotic relationship with single-celled dinoflagellates or green algae. The digestive system is incomplete and functions as both mouth and anus, with waste being excreted through a single opening. They also have a primitive nervous system and musculature for contraction and movement.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Most sea anemones are 1 to 5 cm in diameter and 1.5 to 10 cm in length, but there are species that can be larger, such as Urticina columbiana and Stichodactyla mertensii, which can exceed 1 metre in diameter.
edges.label: size

edges.c: Sea anemones breed by liberating sperm and eggs into the sea. The fertilized eggs develop into planula larvae, which settle on the seabed and develop directly into juvenile polyps. They can also reproduce asexually by breaking in half or into smaller pieces which regenerate into polyps.
edges.label: breeding

edges.c: Anemones entirely lack the free-swimming medusal stage of their life cycle. Both sexual and asexual reproduction can occur.
edges.label: lifeCycle

edges.c: Sea anemones can change their shape dramatically and are capable of locomotion, including creeping, gliding, and swimming. They have the ability to cast themselves loose from the substrate and drift to a new location.
edges.label: movement

edges.c: Sea anemones are predators, capturing prey of suitable size that comes within reach of their tentacles and immobilizing it with the aid of their stinging cells. They typically feed on small fish, crustaceans, and other marine organisms.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Sea anemones are found in both deep oceans and shallow coastal waters worldwide. They are adapted to a variety of environments, including rocks, shells, submerged timber, sand, and mud.
edges.label: habitats

edges.c: Sea anemones and their attendant anemone fish are often harvested from the wild for aquarium exhibits, impacting the populations of both. Fishing activities significantly impact the populations of anemones and anemone fish in exploited areas.
edges.label: aquariumTrade

edges.c: Fossils of sea anemones do exist, with Mackenzia being the oldest fossil identified as a sea anemone from the Middle Cambrian Burgess Shale of Canada.
edges.label: fossilRecord

edges.c: Sea anemones typically have a polyp with a columnar trunk topped by an oral disc with a ring of tentacles and a central mouth. The tentacles are armed with cnidocytes (stinging cells) and can be retracted or expanded. Some species have additional nourishment from symbiotic relationships with single-celled dinoflagellates or green algae.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sea anemones breed by liberating sperm and eggs into the sea, with fertilized eggs developing into planula larvae. Some species live in symbiotic relationships with clownfish, hermit crabs, or small fish.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sea anemones have a gastrovascular cavity functioning as a stomach with a single opening serving as both mouth and anus. They excrete waste through this opening and have a flattened pharynx opening into the gastrovascular cavity divided into chambers by mesenteries.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sea anemones lack a free-swimming medusal stage and reproduce both sexually and asexually. They have great powers of regeneration and can reproduce by budding, fragmentation, or longitudinal or transverse binary fission.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sea anemones are capable of changing shape dramatically and some species are capable of burrowing, walking, or swimming.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sea anemones are found in deep oceans and shallow coastal waters worldwide, clinging onto rocks, shells, or submerged timber. Some species burrow into sand and mud, while others are pelagic.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Sea anemones and their attendant anemone fish are often harvested from the wild as adults or juveniles for aquarium exhibits, impacting the populations of both species in exploited areas.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Fossils of sea anemones are rare, but some species have been identified in the fossil record, such as Mackenzia from the Middle Cambrian Burgess Shale of Canada.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Actiniidae is the largest family of sea anemones, to which most common, temperate, shore species belong. Most members of this family do not participate in symbioses with fishes. Three exceptions are the bubble-tip anemone (with anemonefish and certain cardinalfish), snakelocks anemone (with Incognito goby) and Urticina piscivora (with painted greenling).
edges.label: description

edges.c: Important in defining genera for Actiniidae families. There may be one tentacle per space between mesenteries or there may be more than one tentacle between each two mesenteries. Members of the family Actiniidae have one tentacle per space.
edges.label: Arrangement of tentacles

edges.c: Aegina rosea is a species of hydrozoan of the family Aeginidae. It is circular with a large stomach, two rectangular stomach pouches, jagged margins between each of its 5 or 6 tentacles, nematocysts on the tentacles, and capability of clasping. Its stomach and stomach pouches are magenta, while the tentacles are yellow. It was originally found in the Pacific Northwest and has since been found in the Central Pacific Basin. Its maximum size is believed to be at least 32 millimeters in diameter.

edges.c: Aglantha digitale is a small, transparent, hydrozoan with a maximum height of 4 cm (1.6 in). The bell is thimble-shaped, taller than it is wide, and has a small conical bulge at the apex. It has about eighty slender solid marginal tentacles on the edge of the bell. The gastric peduncle dangles inside the bell, and the mouth at the tip of the small manubrium has four simple lips. Mature individuals have eight white, sausage-shaped gonads which are visible through the bell. This hydrozoan is usually some shade of pink.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Aglantha digitale is found in surface waters in the Arctic and sub-Arctic, occurring above the continental slope but more common over the deep ocean. It seldom occurs at a depth greater than 200 m (660 ft).
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: It is the most common species of jellyfish found in the Arctic and sub-Arctic.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Aglantha digitale is unique among known jellyfish in having giant axons in the subumbrella which are involved in a rapid escape response. When stimulated, it can produce up to three vigorous contractions that propel it a distance of about five body lengths. This rapid escape response may help it to avoid damage to its fragile tissues in its pelagic habitat.
edges.label: unique_feature

edges.c: Agonidae is a family of small, bottom-dwelling, cold-water marine fish known for their elongated bodies covered by scales modified into bony plates. They use their large pectoral fins to move in short bursts. The family includes about 59 species in some 25 genera, and is notable for species like poachers, Irish lords, sea ravens, alligatorfishes, starsnouts, hooknoses, and rockheads. They feed on small crustaceans and marine worms found on the bottom and are found in cold, deep waters of the Northern Hemisphere.
edges.label: description

edges.c: A family of leathery or soft corals characterized by colonies with stiff, hard, and inflexible structures composed of tiny polyps projecting from a shared leathery tissue. Members of the family may have two kinds of polyps: the autozooids with long trunks and eight tiny branched tentacles, and the siphonozooids which remain below the surface and pump water for the colony.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Leathery corals occur globally in temperate and tropical seas. They are often pioneer reef species and are found in wave-exposed areas of reef crests, less turbid waters in lagoons, on steep slopes, under overhangs, and at depths of thirty metres or even deeper.
edges.label: distributionAndHabitat

edges.c: Leathery coral polyps include endosymbiotic algae called zooxanthellae, which undergo photosynthesis and produce sugars from sunlight. This food is shared with the host, which itself provides the algae with minerals and shelter. Periodically, the surface layer of the leathery tissue is shed as a mechanism for ridding the colony of unwanted algal growth.
edges.label: symbioticRelationship

edges.c: A study on the Great Barrier Reef found the population of these corals to be very stable, with little predation, low rates of growth, reproduction, and mortality, and few new colonies coming into existence or disappearing over a three-year period.

edges.c: Amphipoda is an order of malacostracan crustaceans with laterally compressed bodies, no carapace, and a range in size from 1 to 340 millimetres. They are mostly detritivores or scavengers and are found in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial environments. There are more than 9,900 known species of amphipods.

edges.c: The name Amphipoda comes from the Greek roots ἀμφί 'on both/all sides' and πούς 'foot'. They are also known as freshwater shrimp, scuds, or sideswimmers among anglers.

edges.c: Amphipods range in size from less than 1 millimetre to as large as 340 millimetres, with the largest species recorded at 28-34 centimetres in length.

edges.c: Amphipods engage in amplexus for mating, and females bear a marsupium for carrying eggs until they hatch into juvenile forms.

edges.c: Mortality is around 25–50% for the eggs, and there are no larval stages.

edges.c: There are over 10,500 recognized species of amphipods, distributed among several suborders including Gammaridea, Caprellidea, Hyperiidea, and Ingolfiellidea.

edges.c: The recent works in classification have led to the establishment of new suborders and infraorders based on cladistic analysis and molecular data.
edges.label: classification

edges.c: Amphipods are thought to have originated in the Lower Carboniferous, and the fossil record is meagre, with the oldest specimens dating back to the Lower Cretaceous and Upper Eocene.
edges.label: origin

edges.c: Amphipods are found in almost all aquatic environments, from fresh water to the Challenger Deep, and are important components of aquatic ecosystems.
edges.label: habitats

edges.c: Most amphipods are detritivores or scavengers, but some are grazers of algae, omnivores, or predators of small insects and crustaceans.

edges.c: The wolf eel is a species of marine ray-finned fish found in the North Pacific Ocean. Despite its name, it is not a true eel. It can grow up to 2.4 m in length and 18.4 kg in weight. Younger wolf eels are orange with dark spots, while older ones are grey, brown, or dark olive. They have powerful jaws with canine teeth in the front and molars in the posterior portion of the mouth.

edges.c: Eels are ray-finned fish with elongated bodies, ranging from 5 cm to 4 m in length. They lack pelvic fins and many species also lack pectoral fins. Eels are nocturnal and can be found in shallow waters of the ocean as well as deeper waters on continental shelves.

edges.c: Anomura is a group of decapod crustaceans that includes hermit crabs and other varieties. It is the sister group to Brachyura, and together they form the clade Meiura. The name derives from an old classification system and reflects the unusual variety of forms in this group. Anomurans show instances of carcinisation, resulting in the development of a crab-like body form. They have ten pereiopods, with the last pair often reduced in size and hidden inside the gill chamber. Anomurans diverged from Brachyura in the Late Triassic period, and the oldest known fossil attributed to Anomura is Platykotta from the Late Triassic Period in the United Arab Emirates.

edges.c: Anoplogaster cornuta, also known as the common fangtooth, is a deep sea fish found in tropical and temperate oceans worldwide. It has a distinctive appearance with a large bony head, small eyes, and well-armed mouth with sharp fangs. The adults are dark brown to black in color and can grow to a total length of about 18 cm (7 in). Juveniles look different, with a much paler color and triangular cross-section.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The common fangtooth is found in tropical and temperate waters in both the eastern and western Atlantic Ocean, the Indian Ocean, and the Pacific Ocean. It inhabits depths ranging from 2 to 5,000 metres, with adults usually found between 500 and 5,000 metres and juveniles near the surface.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: It is a pelagic fish occurring in deep waters, often forming small groups or being solitary. Juveniles are found at lesser depths.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The common fangtooth is a predator feeding on other fish, crustaceans, and cephalopods. It is preyed upon by tunas, marlins, and albacores. The fish breeds in the summer months and the developing larvae are planktonic. It is oviparous and lives for at least three years based on otolith examination.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Studies have shown that the common fangtooth is able to regulate its respiratory system according to its environment, and its respiration rate is directly proportional to its size. The fish has evolved features that make it nearly invisible in its deep-sea habitat, including efficient light absorption using melanin pigments in its dermis.
edges.label: research

edges.c: Antedonidae is a family of crinoids or feather stars in the phylum Echinodermata. Members of the family are unstalked and have ten feathery arms. They can move about freely and have clawed cirri to attach them temporarily to structures.

edges.c: Antipathes is a genus of coral in the order Antipatharia, composed of black coral with a black skeleton. It contains symmetrically aligned as well as irregularly shaped corals, a range of different colors, and colonies that can be either sparsely branched or closely packed. The polyps for these corals have six tentacles that are each lined with stinging cells. They lack photosynthesizing algae and prefer to live in deeper waters near currents to catch and eat passing zooplankton.

edges.c: Aphyonidae is a family of eel-like fishes. They are small, typically about 10 centimetres long when fully grown, and have transparent, gelatinous skin without scales. Their dorsal, caudal, and anal fins are united into a single ribbon. Most species exhibit neoteny, retaining larval features as adults. They have partially calcified skeleton, underdeveloped muscles and gills, reduced eyes, nasal organ and lateral line, and lack a swim bladder. Aphyonids are viviparous, with males producing sperm sacs for extended storage, enabling mating with immature females who can store the sperm until reaching sexual maturity.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Arachnactidae is a family of tube-dwelling anemones in the order Ceriantharia. It is the only family in the monotypic order Penicillaria and comprises around 38 species. They differ from other ceriantharians in the makeup of their cnidome, the relative sizes of the oral discs, and the shape and structure of the mesenteries. These tube anemones dwell in parchment-like tubes immersed in soft sediment, and have two whorls of tentacles, the outer ones being much longer than the inner ones.

edges.c: The Arcturidae are a family of marine isopod crustaceans in the suborder Valvifera. They resemble woodlice and are found globally in cooler areas in shallow seas. The head is incapable of rotating laterally with well-developed eyes and mouthparts that do not form a suctorial cone or proboscis. The thorax or pereon is smooth or slightly sculptured and sometimes spinose or rugose. A flexion occurs between it and the abdomen or pleon, giving the animal an arched appearance from a lateral view.

edges.c: Arthropods are invertebrates in the phylum Arthropoda. They possess an exoskeleton with a cuticle made of chitin, often mineralized with calcium carbonate, a body with differentiated (metameric) segments, and paired jointed appendages.
edges.label: Definition

edges.c: Arthropods have an exoskeleton with a cuticle made of chitin and often mineralized with calcium carbonate.
edges.label: Exoskeleton

edges.c: Arthropods must go through stages of moulting, a process by which they shed their exoskeleton to reveal a new one.
edges.label: Growth

edges.c: Arthropods are an extremely diverse group, with up to 10 million species.
edges.label: Diversity

edges.c: Arthropods have a variety of respiratory systems depending on their environment and subphylum. They may use gills, tracheae, or other mechanisms for respiration.
edges.label: RespiratorySystem

edges.c: Arthropods have an open circulatory system with haemolymph functioning as the analogue of blood.
edges.label: CirculatorySystem

edges.c: The nervous system is 'ladder-like', with paired ventral nerve cords running through all segments and forming paired ganglia in each segment.
edges.label: Structure

edges.c: Arthropods have specialized sensory organs, including compound eyes, pigment-pit ocelli for vision, along with various chemical and mechanical sensors.
edges.label: Specialization

edges.c: Most terrestrial species use internal fertilization, while aquatic species use either internal or external fertilization. Some arthropods are viviparous, and others lay eggs.
edges.label: Reproduction

edges.c: Arthropod hatchlings vary in forms, from miniature adults to grubs and caterpillars, and undergo a total metamorphosis to produce the adult form.

edges.c: The test is small and subglobular with fragile plating which is firmly tessellated. The apical disc is monocyclic. The plates membrane is embedded and does not touch the coronal plates. The ambulacral plating is pseudocompound with single large primary tubercle on every third plate which is much enlarged compared to the others. The primary tubercles form an alternate series down the perradius. These traits distinguish this genus from Plesiodiadema and Gymnotiara. The primary tubercles are perforated and notched. The secondary tuberculation confined to plate margins. The peristome has shallow, rounded buccal notches. The spines are slender and arranged in whorls. The lumens are filled with a mesh of horizontal dividers and vertical pillars.
edges.label: description

edges.c: A biofilm is a syntrophic community of microorganisms in which cells stick to each other and often also to a surface. These adherent cells become embedded within a slimy extracellular matrix that is composed of extracellular polymeric substances (EPSs). The cells within the biofilm produce the EPS components, which are typically a polymeric combination of extracellular polysaccharides, proteins, lipids, and DNA.
edges.label: definition

edges.c: Biofilms are thought to have arisen during primitive Earth as a defense mechanism for prokaryotes, as the conditions at that time were too harsh for their survival.
edges.label: primitive Earth

edges.c: Biofilms may form on living (biotic) or non-living (abiotic) surfaces and can be common in natural, industrial, and hospital settings. The formation of a biofilm begins with the attachment of free-floating microorganisms to a surface.
edges.label: factors

edges.c: The first colonist bacteria of a biofilm may adhere to the surface initially by weak van der Waals forces and hydrophobic effects. If the colonists are not immediately separated from the surface, they can anchor themselves more permanently using cell adhesion structures such as pili.
edges.label: attachment

edges.c: Dispersal of cells from the biofilm colony is an essential stage of the biofilm life cycle as it enables biofilms to spread and colonize new surfaces.
edges.label: dispersal

edges.c: Biofilms are usually found on solid substrates submerged in or exposed to an aqueous solution, although they can form as floating mats on liquid surfaces and also on the surface of leaves, particularly in high humidity climates. Biofilms can attach to a surface such as a tooth or rock, and may include a single species or a diverse group of microorganisms.
edges.label: habitats

edges.c: Around two-thirds of bacterial infections in humans involve biofilms. Infections associated with biofilm growth are usually challenging to eradicate. This is mostly due to the fact that mature biofilms display antimicrobial tolerance and immune response evasions.
edges.label: medicine

edges.c: For example, many sewage treatment plants include a secondary treatment stage in which waste water passes over biofilms grown on filters, which extract and digest organic compounds.
edges.label: industry

edges.c: Biofilms have become problematic in several food industries due to the ability to form on plants and during industrial processes. Bacteria can survive long periods of time in water, animal manure, and soil, causing biofilm formation on plants or in the processing equipment.
edges.label: food_industry

edges.c: It happens frequently in prokaryotes, and less frequently in eukaryotes. Biofilms promote horizontal gene transfer in a variety of ways.
edges.label: horizontal_gene_transfer

edges.c: Most of the time, the tripodfish stands on its three fins on the bottom of the ocean, hunting for food. Its fins are presumably quite stiff, but can be flexible when swimming. Scientists have suggested that fluids are pumped into these fins when the fish is 'standing' to make them more rigid.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Uses tactile and mechanosensory cues to identify food and does not have special visual adaptations. The fish faces into the current, waiting for prey to drift by and senses objects in the water with its front fins, which act like hands. Once they feel prey and realize it is edible, the fins knock the food into the fish's mouth.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Each individual has male and female reproductive organs. If two tripodfish happen to meet, they mate. However, if a tripodfish does not find a partner, it makes both sperm and eggs to produce offspring by itself.

edges.c: Bembradium is diagnosed as a genus by the front part of the head behind very flattened, becoming less flattened to the rear. The lower jaw does not protrude. The suborbital ridge bears many spines. The origin of the pectoral fins is behind a vertical line through the origin of the pelvic fins. The lateral line runs through the centre of the flanks. The scales on the body are large.

edges.c: Benthopectinidae is a family of sea stars with at least 75 species in eight genera. It is the only family in the monotypic order Notomyotida. These deep-sea dwelling sea stars have flexible arms and characteristic longitudinal muscle bands on the inner dorso-lateral surface of the arms. Many of its members are expected to have a greater range than is currently recognized.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Beroe abyssicola is a pelagic ctenophore species that inhabits the North Pacific. It has a muscular, flat, and cylindrical body, lacking tentacles in any life stage, and can grow up to 7 cm long. Its body is more opaque than other ctenophores and can have red or purple coloration. It has a large mouth that it keeps closed using adhesive bands of epithelial cells when not feeding.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Large and adhesive, used to swallow prey whole

edges.c: Aboral organ mediates swimming, gravity sensing, and other functions. Sensory cells surrounding the mouth detect chemical and mechanical stimuli.

edges.c: Transparent, sac-like, often somewhat compressed, with a maximum length of about 15 cm. Wide mouth at one end. Eight longitudinal rows of cilia extending from the aboral end, with a shimmering effect. General body color is pink, with bioluminescent plates and a figure of eight-shaped ring of small papillae around the aboral tip. Gastrovascular channels extend from the stomach through the body wall beneath the rows of cilia.
edges.label: body

edges.c: Beroe gracilis is a translucent, elongated, hollow, cylindrical comb jelly with a maximum length of about 4 cm (1.6 in). It lacks tentacles and has a gaping mouth at the broader anterior end. It possesses a statocyst at the posterior end and eight rows of combs with cilia which propel the animal forward, creating multicoloured sparkles. The body wall is slightly milky, sometimes bluish or pinkish in color, allowing the gut and diverticula to be visible.
edges.label: description

edges.c: It is found in the North Sea, the Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, and occasionally in the Baltic Sea, with its range extending from Norway to Morocco. It also occurs in the northeastern Pacific Ocean and cold deep waters off the Bahamas. In recent years, specimens were collected off the coast of Chile, marking the first records from the Southern Hemisphere. Beroe gracilis is part of the nekton, actively swimming in the top 100 m (330 ft) of the water column.
edges.label: distributionAndHabitat

edges.c: Beroe gracilis is a voracious predator, feeding almost exclusively on other comb jellies, such as Pleurobrachia pileus. It captures prey by swimming rapidly with its mouth open wide and processes it using specialized cilia. It primarily preys on the warty comb jelly Mnemiopsis leidyi, which has become invasive in European waters. While Beroe gracilis readily preys on M. leidyi, it is limited in controlling the alien species by its inability to ingest prey approaching its own size.
edges.label: ecology

edges.c: The alfonsino has large eyes, a deep, compressed body with a rose red dorsally, orange ventrally, and silvery-pink body. It can reach lengths of up to 100.0 cm (39.4 in) TL and a maximum weight of 2.5 kg (5.5 lb).
edges.label: physicalCharacteristics

edges.c: Its bright red color serves as an adaptation to deepwater surroundings where red is filtered out of the light spectrum.
edges.label: adaptations

edges.c: Bivalvia is a class of marine and freshwater molluscs with laterally compressed bodies enclosed by a shell consisting of two hinged parts. The class includes clams, oysters, cockles, mussels, scallops, and numerous other families that live in saltwater, as well as a number of families that live in freshwater. Most bivalves are filter feeders that bury themselves in sediment for protection. The total number of known living species is about 9,200, placed within 1,260 genera and 106 families.

edges.c: Bonellia viridis, also known as the green spoonworm, is a marine worm noted for its exceptional sexual dimorphism and the biocidal properties of a pigment in its skin. The female has a pale- to dark-green body, reaching a length of 15 cm, and lives at depths of 10 to 100 meters. It is primarily a detritivore, also feeding on small animals. The male, rarely observed, is flat and unpigmented, growing to only 1–3 mm, and lives on or inside the body of a female.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Bonellia viridis is found in the north-eastern Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The adult female produces a vivid green pigment in its skin known as bonellin, which is highly toxic to other organisms and has biocidal properties. It is being investigated as a possible model for novel antibiotics.
edges.label: pigment

edges.c: The sex of a green spoonworm is determined by external, environmental factors (the presence or absence of bonellin), not by internal, genetic factors, as is the case with most other sexually-differentiated organisms.
edges.label: environmentalSexDetermination

edges.c: Crabs are decapod crustaceans with a short projecting 'tail', typically hidden under the thorax. They are found in all of the world's oceans, freshwater, and on land, and have a thick exoskeleton and a single pair of pincers on each arm. They first appeared during the Jurassic Period.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Crabs are covered with a thick exoskeleton composed primarily of highly mineralized chitin.
edges.label: exoskeleton

edges.c: Crabs vary in size from a few millimeters wide to a leg span of up to 4 m (13 ft).
edges.label: size

edges.c: Crabs breathe through gills on their underside.
edges.label: breathing

edges.c: Crabs often show marked sexual dimorphism, with males having larger claws and different abdominal shapes.
edges.label: sexual dimorphism

edges.c: Most crabs have internal fertilization and mate belly-to-belly. Females often carry fertilized eggs on their abdomen and release the larvae into the water after development.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Crabs typically walk sideways, are aggressive toward one another, and are omnivores, feeding primarily on algae and other food sources.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Crabs are consumed worldwide as a dish prepared in various ways. Some species are eaten whole, while others have specific components consumed in different cultures.
edges.label: human consumption

edges.c: The earliest unambiguous crab fossils date from the Early Jurassic. Crabs radiated in the Late Jurassic, increased in diversity through the Cretaceous, and represented the dominant group of decapods by the end of the period.
edges.label: evolution

edges.c: Crabs are found in all of the world's oceans, freshwater, and on land, particularly in tropical regions. About 850 species are freshwater crabs.
edges.label: environment

edges.c: Crabs make up 20% of all marine crustaceans caught, farmed, and consumed worldwide, amounting to 1.5 million tonnes annually.
edges.label: fisheries

edges.c: Crabs are prepared and eaten as a dish in many different ways all over the world, and some species are particularly valued for their meat.
edges.label: cookery

edges.c: The earliest unambiguous crab fossils date from the Early Jurassic.
edges.label: fossils

edges.c: Crabs radiated in the Late Jurassic, increased in diversity through the Cretaceous, and represented the dominant group of decapods by the end of the period.
edges.label: radiation

edges.c: The infraorder Brachyura contains approximately 7,000 species in 98 families, and the evolution of crabs is characterized by an increasingly robust body and a reduction in the abdomen.
edges.label: taxonomy

edges.c: Crabs have influenced various mythologies and cultural beliefs, and are depicted in constellations, astrological signs, and ancient art.
edges.label: mythology

edges.c: Brisingids are deep-sea-dwelling starfish in the order Brisingida. They have between 6 and 18 long, attenuated arms which they use for suspension feeding. Other characteristics include a single series of marginals, a fused ring of disc plates, the lack of actinal plates, a spool-like ambulacral column, reduced abactinal plates, and crossed pedicellariae. They are 40 times the size of disk radius and have 7–20 flexible spiny arms.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Brisingidae is a family of deep-sea starfish found in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans as well as in the Southern Ocean and around Antarctica. It was named after the necklace Brísingamen from Norse mythology.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Small, Ophiurida-like disc with a rim of fused plates for rigidity
edges.label: disc

edges.c: Long and tapering with an acute angle between them, can be shed at the base
edges.label: arms

edges.c: Small on the aboral side and armed with spines on the upper side of the arms
edges.label: plates

edges.c: Broad with a row of tube feet with suckers on either side
edges.label: ambulacral groove

edges.c: Hard surfaces at depths between 100 and 4,500 m (300 and 14,800 ft)
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Filter feed on suspended organic particles by raising their arms vertically above their discs
edges.label: feeding

edges.c: Dark brown with a submarginal black band and narrow white border on the dorsal and anal fins
edges.label: male

edges.c: Greenish to orange brown with orange-bordered dorsal and anal fins

nodes: cystid, which provides the body wall and produces the exoskeleton

edges.c: Bryozoa, also known as Polyzoa, Ectoprocta, or commonly as moss animals, are a phylum of simple, aquatic invertebrate animals, nearly all living in sedentary colonies. They have a special feeding structure called a lophophore, a 'crown' of tentacles used for filter feeding.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Lophophore, a 'crown' of tentacles used for filter feeding
edges.label: feedingStructure

edges.c: Most marine bryozoans live in tropical waters, but a few are found in oceanic trenches and polar waters
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The terms Polyzoa and Bryozoa were introduced in 1830 and 1831, respectively. Soon after it was named, another group of animals was discovered whose filtering mechanism looked similar, so it was included in Bryozoa until 1869, when the two groups were noted to be very different internally.
edges.label: introduction

edges.c: Disagreements about terminology persisted well into the 20th century, but 'Bryozoa' is now the generally accepted term.
edges.label: namingDispute

edges.c: 5,869 living species are known, with at least two genera being solitary (Aethozooides and Monobryozoon) and the rest being colonial.
edges.label: diversity

edges.c: Colonies take a variety of forms, including fans, bushes, and sheets. Single animals, called zooids, live throughout the colony and are not fully independent.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Responsible for feeding, excretion, and supplying nutrients to the colony through diverse channels
edges.label: autozooids

edges.c: Some classes have specialist zooids like hatcheries for fertilized eggs, colonial defense structures, and root-like attachment structures.
edges.label: specialistZooids

edges.c: cystid, which provides the body wall and produces the exoskeleton
edges.label: components

edges.c: Zooids of all the freshwater species are simultaneous hermaphrodites. Although those of many marine species function first as males and then as females, their colonies always contain a combination of zooids that are in their male and female stages.
edges.label: hermaphrodites

edges.c: After settling, all larvae undergo a radical metamorphosis that destroys and rebuilds almost all the internal tissues.
edges.label: larvae

edges.c: Some species emit sperm into the water and also release ova into the water, while others capture sperm via their tentacles to fertilize their ova internally.
edges.label: defense

edges.c: Mineralized skeletons of bryozoans first appear in rocks from the Early Ordovician period, making it the last major phylum to appear in the fossil record.
edges.label: appearance

edges.c: It is uncertain whether the phylum is monophyletic and their evolutionary relationships to other phyla are also unclear.
edges.label: evolution

edges.c: Bryozoans, phoronids, and brachiopods strain food out of the water by means of a lophophore, a 'crown' of hollow tentacles. Bryozoans form colonies consisting of clones called zooids that are typically about 0.5 mm (1⁄64 in) long.
edges.label: distinguishingFeatures

edges.c: Buccinidae is a large and diverse taxonomic family of sea snails, commonly known as whelks. The family includes more than 1500 species and is characterized by moderate to large-sized shells, conical to fusiform in shape, with deep sutures and a generally smooth surface. They are carnivorous and scavengers, feeding on clams, carrion, and detritus. The female whelk lays spongy egg capsules with hundreds of eggs. The flesh of the common northern whelk, Buccinum undatum, is highly valued as a food item. The empty shells of whelks are often used by hermit crabs as homes.
edges.label: description

edges.c: True whelks are found worldwide in all seas, from tropical oceans to the cold seas of the Arctic and Southern Oceans. They inhabit a wide range of depths, from the intertidal to the bathypelagic zones. While most prefer a solid bottom, some inhabit sandy substrates.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Bluish or yellowish, live exclusively in very deep water, move by swinging their bodies from side to side
edges.label: description

edges.c: Covered by a transparent mucus sheath, have a cephalic cage, prominent parapodia, first described in 1885 from deep waters off Sierra Leone
edges.label: description

edges.c: Covered by a thick mucus sheath, have less than ten segments, covered with papillae, bioluminescence reported, first described off southwestern Chile in 1967
edges.label: description

edges.c: Grows to between 20 and 30 mm long, found at depths between 4000 and 6000 metres below sea level near Kuril-Kamchatka trench in the Pacific Ocean, thick and translucent gelatinous sheath, originally described in 1977
edges.label: description

edges.c: Genus Flota described with one species (F. flabelligera) in the family Flabelligeridae by Olga Hartman
Genus transferred by Hartman into the newly-erected Fauveliopsidae
A second species, Flota vitjasi, is described by Galina N. Buzhinskaja
Flota placed in new family, Flotidae, erected by Buzhinskaja
Rouse considers Flota very close to Poeobiidae, and placed both in Flabelligeridae
Buzhinskaja defends the family status of Flotidae and re-establishes it
Flota species are transferred to within Buskiella
meso- and bathypelagic layers, Subantarctic to Subarctic Ocean
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: ventral edge of anterior lateral fin
edges.label: location

edges.c: hexagonal chambers with elongate ovoid particles
edges.label: composition

edges.c: allow them to catch weak light at bathypelagic depths
edges.label: photoreceptiveRegions

edges.c: highly unstable and rapidly inactivated at ice-cold temperatures
edges.label: luciferase

edges.c: C. macrocephala has been found to consist of at least two cryptic species
edges.label: additionalInfo

edges.c: Caenogastropoda is a taxonomic subclass of molluscs in the class Gastropoda. It is a large diverse group which are mostly sea snails and other marine gastropod mollusks, but also includes some freshwater snails and some land snails. The subclass is the most diverse and ecologically successful of the gastropods.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Caenogastropoda contains many families of shelled marine molluscs – including the periwinkles, cowries, wentletraps, moon snails, murexes, cone snails and turrids – and constitutes about 60% of all living gastropods.
edges.label: diversity

edges.c: The taxon Caenogastropoda was first established by Leslie Reginald Cox in 1960 as a superorder but now sometimes it is retained as a clade.
edges.label: establishment

edges.c: Equivalent to the older Mesogastropoda, with typically seven teeth in each radular row.
edges.label: taenioglossa

edges.c: The Neogastropoda, with only 1–3 teeth per row.
edges.label: stenoglossa

edges.c: The Caenogastropoda exhibit torsion, and thus are included in what was previously called the Streptoneura (meaning twisted nerves), also known as Prosobranchia (meaning gills forward). Specifically, they are characterized by having only a single auricle in the heart and a single pair of gill leaflets.
edges.label: characteristics

edges.c: They are equivalent to the Monotocardia or Pectinibranchia of older authors.
edges.label: anatomy

edges.c: Colgan et al. (2006) provided further insight into the phylogeny of Caenogastropoda.
edges.label: phylogeny_insight

edges.c: Caenopedina hawaiiensis is a species of sea urchins known for their spiny armor.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Calappidae is a family of crabs containing 16 genera, 7 of which are known only as fossils. Fossils within this family can be found in sediment of Europe, United States, Mexico, Central America, Australia, and Japan from the Cretaceous to recent times.
edges.label: description

nodes: Rapidly bury themselves under the sand to hide from predators
Capable of producing foul-tasting and -smelling substances as a defense mechanism

edges.c: Dragonets are small, colorful, marine fish belonging to the family Callionymidae. They are benthic organisms found mainly in the tropical waters of the western Indo-Pacific. There are 139 known species of dragonets, characterized by their elongated, scaleless bodies and showy fins.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Dragonets inhabit sandy bottoms at depths of around 200 meters in the tropical waters of the western Indo-Pacific.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Dragonet spawning occurs during late afternoons, involving distinct stages of courtship display, pairing, ascending, and the release of eggs and milt. Males are polygynous and will spawn with multiple females in a reproductive day. Females do not guard their offspring, and the released eggs float freely in the water column.
edges.label: spawning

edges.c: Dragonets feed on benthic sources including copepods, amphipods, and other small invertebrates living on sea grass. Their feeding behavior occurs throughout the day and is not territorial.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Rapidly bury themselves under the sand to hide from predators
edges.label: defense_mechanisms

edges.c: Capable of producing foul-tasting and -smelling substances as a defense mechanism
edges.label: defense_mechanisms

edges.c: Many species exhibit marked sexual dimorphism, with males and females colored and patterned differently. Male dragonets are larger and have longer fins than females.
edges.label: sexual_dimorphism

edges.c: Calliostomatidae is a family of sea snails within the superfamily Trochoidea and the clade Vetigastropoda.
edges.label: definition

edges.c: The Calliostomatidae are unusually diverse. They are characterized by a stepped spire and a pointy aperture. They may possess or lack an umbilicus. The collumella is sometimes thicker, partially covering the aperture. The spiral whorls can differ between narrow and robust. They inhabit a wide range of ocean habitats, from the intertidal zone to mid-bathyal depths.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Calliostomatidae stays in Trochoidea. Up to 2008 there were only two species Calliostoma javanicum and Calliostoma unicum that were used in molecular phylogeny studies.
edges.label: note

edges.c: Thysanodontinae Marshall, 1988 belongs to the family Calliostomatidae, confirmed based on molecular data.
edges.label: note

edges.c: The tribe Fautricini B. A. Marshall, 1995 was raised to the rank of subfamily Fautricinae B. A. Marshall, 1995
edges.label: note

edges.c: Callistoctopus is a genus of nocturnal, orange octopuses in the family Octopodidae. They are readily identifiable by their reddish coloring, the white papillae that line their bodies, and their long arms. Though sympatric with diurnal Octopus species, they avoid competition by hunting at night. Many species of Callistoctopus are referred to as night octopuses due to their preference for hunting at night.
edges.label: description

edges.c: On eleven new species of the Cephalopoda from Japan, including two new genera of the Octopodinae
edges.label: title

edges.c: Callogorgia is a genus of soft corals in the family Primnoidae, with a fan-shaped body structure that serves as a habitat for other organisms. They are found in the upper bathyal region of the sea at depths ranging from 750 to 8200 feet, and are distributed across the world, from the Atlantic to the Indo-Pacific.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Mature eggs enter the body cavity and are spawned via the mouth, leading to the growth of a planktonic disc-shaped larva. The early growth of tentacles, body cavity, and mouth begins their change into adults. Callogorgia cling to a surface in the water as they mature into adults.
edges.label: process

edges.c: From the Atlantic to the Indo-Pacific
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: They can reside in brackish water as well, areas with less salinity than true marine environments. Each species of Callogorgia will bunch together in dense colonies, inhabiting a unique site of ecological parameters. They are often found with brittle stars attached to their branches.
edges.label: additional_info

edges.c: commensal relationship, with the ophiurans benefitting by the elevation provided by Callogorgia, allowing them to suspension feed
edges.label: brittle stars

edges.c: use Callogorgia as a nursery habitat by depositing their egg cases on the branches of the sponge
edges.label: cat sharks

edges.c: Threats to Callogorgia include damage from fishing gear and equipment, climate change, and ocean acidification, all of which can hinder their growth and long-term survival.
edges.label: additional_info

edges.c: Vesicomyidae is a family of saltwater clams, marine bivalve molluscs in the superfamily Glossoidea.
edges.label: definition

edges.c: Kuroda, 1931 : synonym of † Pleurophopsis uchimuraensis (Kuroda, 1931)  (original combination)
edges.label: Adulomya uchimuraensis

edges.c: synonym of Pleurophopsis van Winkle, 1919 (unjustified emendation of Pleurophopsis)
edges.label: Pleurophoropsis

edges.c: Calyptogena magnifica is a species of giant white clam found clustered around hydrothermal vents at abyssal depths in the Pacific Ocean. It was first described in 1980 and is specially adapted to life around hydrothermal vents by hosting chemosymbiotic bacteria in its gills.
edges.label: description

edges.c: about two times as long as they are high
edges.label: size

edges.c: exterior is white and usually chalky in appearance, periostracum is yellowish brown, wrinkled, and loose
edges.label: color

edges.c: large pink protrusible foot divided into two portions
edges.label: foot

edges.c: two separate siphons, short, do not extend beyond the edge of the valves
edges.label: siphons

edges.c: large and thick, host chemosymbiotic bacteria
edges.label: gills

edges.c: thermal vents on the East Pacific Rise between 21°N and 22°S, Galapagos Rift, 200 miles west of Punta Mita, Mexico at a depth of 2,645 metres
edges.label: location

edges.c: present at some vents, absent at others
edges.label: abundance

edges.c: absorbs nutrients produced by chemosymbiotic bacteria in its gills
edges.label: feeding

edges.c: specially adapted foot for burrowing and moving on the sea floor, no longer has guts, hosts chemosymbiotic bacteria
edges.label: adaptations

edges.c: poor dispersal abilities, larvae disperse to other vents throughout its range
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: thermal vents in the deep sea floor
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: part of a rich benthic community with mussels, galatheid crabs, shrimps, and octopuses
edges.label: community

edges.c: Found in almost all world oceans
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Canalipalpata is an order of polychaete worms, with 31 families, including suborder Sabellida and the Alvinellidae family of deep-sea worms associated with hydrothermal vents. They are known for being filter feeders with grooved palpi covered in cilia.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Many species of Canalipalpata are visually attractive and recommended for marine aquariums.
edges.label: useInAquaria

edges.c: Cancridae is a family of crabs comprising six extant genera and ten exclusively fossil genera in two subfamilies.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Until 2000, the extant species were all classified in genus Cancer. After an analysis of new fossil material, the subgenera were elevated to the rank of genus, and three new genera were erected. Most of the family's current diversity is found in temperate waters of the Northern Hemisphere.
edges.label: discovery

edges.c: Peter Davie; Michael Türkay (2011). 'Cancridae'. World Register of Marine Species.
edges.label: source

edges.c: Caprellidae is a family of amphipods commonly known as skeleton shrimps. Their common name denotes the threadlike slender body which allows them to virtually disappear among the fine filaments of seaweed, hydroids and bryozoans. They are sometimes also known as ghost shrimps.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Highly reduced and almost invisible, attached to the posterior of the seventh pereonite
edges.label: abdomen

edges.c: Two pairs of antennae, with the first pair usually longer than the second pair. Each pereonite has a pair of appendages known as pereopods. The first two pairs are modified into raptorial appendages known as gnathopods. The third and fourth pair of pereopods are usually reduced or absent altogether. The fifth to seventh pair of pereopods are smaller than the gnathopods and are used for clasping objects.
edges.label: appendages

edges.c: Males are usually far larger than the females.
edges.label: sexualDimorphism

edges.c: Low intertidal zones and subtidal waters among eelgrass, hydroids and bryozoans
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Omnivorous, feeding on diatoms, detritus, protozoans, smaller amphipods, and crustacean larvae. Some species are filter feeders, using their antennae to filter food from the water or scrape it off the substrate. Most species are predators that sit and wait like a praying mantis, with their gnathopods ready to snatch any smaller invertebrates which come along.
edges.label: feedingHabits

edges.c: Can only occur when the female is between the new and hardened exoskeletons
edges.label: mating

edges.c: After mating the female will brood the fertilized eggs within her brood pouch. The young will hatch and emerge as juvenile adults.
edges.label: brooding

edges.c: In some species, the female has been known to kill the males by injecting venom from a claw within their gnathopod.
edges.label: behaviorAfterMating

edges.c: Superfamily Caprelloidea, infraorder Caprellida, suborder Corophiidea
edges.label: classification

edges.c: Media related to Caprellidae at Wikimedia Commons
edges.label: media

edges.c: Data related to Caprellidae at Wikispecies
edges.label: data

edges.c: The silvertip shark (Carcharhinus albimarginatus) is a large species of requiem shark in the family Carcharhinidae.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The silvertip shark is widely but not continuously distributed in the tropical Indian and Pacific Oceans. It is found over continental and insular shelves at a depth of 30–800 m (98–2,625 ft), occupying all levels of the water column.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The silvertip shark is a robust and streamlined species with a blue-gray coloration above with a bronze sheen, and white below. It can grow up to 3 m (9.8 ft) long and has a maximum reported weight of 162.2 kg (358 lb).
edges.label: physical_description

edges.c: The diet of the silvertip shark consists primarily of bony fishes, eagle rays, smaller sharks, and cephalopods.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Like other requiem sharks, the silvertip shark is viviparous, with females giving birth to one to 11 pups in the summer.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Silvertip sharks are aggressive apex predators and exhibit territorial behavior. They are often encountered alone or in pairs.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: The silvertip shark is regarded as potentially dangerous to humans and has been known to approach divers closely.
edges.label: danger_to_humans

edges.c: The International Union for Conservation of Nature has assessed the silvertip shark as vulnerable due to overfishing and population declines.
edges.label: conservation_status

nodes: Some species covered in prickly spines
C. fulvus has a commensal relationship with glass sponges
Several species are parasitic on king crabs

edges.c: Careproctus is a genus of snailfishes found in benthic and benthopelagic habitats in the Atlantic, Pacific, Arctic, and Southern Oceans. They range from shallow coastal seas in the far north of their range to the abyssal zone, at depths of 6 to 5,459 meters.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Some species of Careproctus are known to have unusual breeding behaviors and some are parasitic on king crabs.
edges.label: speciality

edges.c: Some species covered in prickly spines
edges.label: features

edges.c: Up to 54 cm in standard length
edges.label: size

edges.c: Most species of Careproctus feed on small animals.
edges.label: feeding_habits

edges.c: C. fulvus has a commensal relationship with glass sponges
edges.label: breeding

edges.c: Several species are parasitic on king crabs
edges.label: breeding

edges.c: Northeastern Pacific Ocean at depths of 1,920–2,910 m
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Elongated fish with gelatinous skin, no scales, large pectoral fins, pelvic fins modified into adhesive disc, maximum length of 43 cm
edges.label: physicalCharacteristics

edges.c: Simple, sharp recurved teeth in a single narrow band
edges.label: teeth

edges.c: Thought to be a mouth brooder
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Carrying developing eggs in his mouth
edges.label: male

edges.c: Had undeveloped ovaries with small eggs
edges.label: immature females

edges.c: Had fewer large-yolked eggs in their ovaries
edges.label: mature females

edges.c: Found off northern British Columbia and off Washington state
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Caridea is an infraorder of shrimp within the order Decapoda, commonly known as caridean shrimp or true shrimp. They are found widely around the world in both fresh and salt water.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Carideans are found in every kind of aquatic habitat, with the majority of species being marine. Around a quarter of the described species are found in fresh water.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: They vary greatly in form, from species a few millimetres long when fully grown, to those that grow to over a foot long.
edges.label: size

edges.c: Most carideans are omnivorous, but some are specialised for particular modes of feeding. Some are filter feeders, using their setose (bristly) legs as a sieve; some scrape algae from rocks.
edges.label: feedingHabit

edges.c: Carideans brood their eggs rather than releasing them into the water. Caridean larvae undergo all naupliar development within the egg, and eclose as a zoea.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: The decapodid larva will metamorphose a final time into a post-larval juvenile, resembling a miniature adult but retaining some larval characteristics.
edges.label: metamorphosis

edges.c: The most significant commercial species among the carideans is Pandalus borealis, followed by Crangon crangon. The global aquaculture of all shrimp and prawn species slightly exceeded the global wild capture. No carideans were significantly involved in aquaculture, but about 13% of the global wild capture, or about 6% of the total production of all shrimp and prawns, were carideans.
edges.label: fishing

edges.c: The gill structure is lamellar in carideans but branching in dendrobranchiates.
edges.label: gillStructure

edges.c: The easiest practical way to separate true shrimp from dendrobranchiates is to examine the second abdominal segment.
edges.label: abdominalSegment

edges.c: Carideans typically have two pairs of chelae (claws), while dendrobranchiates have three.
edges.label: chelae

edges.c: Stenopodidea differs from carideans and dendrobranchiates in that the third pairs of legs is greatly enlarged.
edges.label: thirdLegs

edges.c: Cephalopods are a class of marine animals characterized by bilateral body symmetry, a prominent head, and a set of arms or tentacles.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Squid are cephalopods of the order Teuthida. They are marine animals known for their elongated bodies, large eyes, and two long tentacles.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Squid are found in all the world's oceans, predominantly in the euphotic zone.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Octopuses are soft-bodied mollusks of the order Octopoda. They belong to the class Cephalopoda and are known for their eight arms and bulbous heads.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Octopuses inhabit many diverse regions of the ocean, including coral reefs, pelagic waters, and the seafloor.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Cuttlefish are marine mollusks of the order Sepiida. They have a unique internal structure called the cuttlebone and are known for their ability to change color and texture.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Cuttlefish are found in shallow coastal waters, but some species are also found at considerable depths.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Nautiluses are primitive cephalopods that belong to the subclass Nautiloidea. They are characterized by their spiral-shaped shells and many tentacles.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Nautiluses inhabit deep waters near the ocean floor, typically in the Indo-Pacific region.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Cephalopods are characterized by their bilateral body symmetry, prominent heads, and a set of arms or tentacles. They are exclusively marine animals and exhibit a wide range of sizes, from very small species to the massive colossal squid.
edges.label: physical_description

edges.c: Cephalopods are widely regarded as intelligent invertebrates with well-developed senses and large brains. They exhibit complex behaviors, including problem-solving, hunting, and social interactions. Some cephalopods are known to change their color and patterns rapidly for signaling and camouflage purposes.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Cephalopods have advanced vision, gravity detection using statocysts, and a variety of chemical sense organs. They rely on vision to detect predators and prey and use their arms and tentacles for exploration.
edges.label: senses

edges.c: Cephalopods reproduce sexually, with males and females exhibiting sexual dimorphism. They employ various mating strategies, including male-male competition, mate choice, and complex courtship behaviors. Some species store sperm and exhibit polyandrous behavior.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Cephalopods play essential roles in marine ecosystems as predators and prey. They contribute to nutrient cycling and food webs, influencing the abundance and distribution of various marine organisms.
edges.label: ecological_role

edges.c: Cephalopods are found in all the world's oceans, from the surface to the deep-sea, and can inhabit a wide range of marine environments, including coral reefs, coastal waters, and open ocean.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Their diversity is greatest near the equator, with a decrease in species richness towards the poles. They are also found in the hadal zone, the deepest part of the ocean.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The study of cephalopods is important in various scientific fields, including neuroscience, marine biology, and evolutionary biology. They are used as model organisms for studying learning, memory, and behavior.
edges.label: scientific_research

edges.c: Cephalopods play a significant role in marine food webs, serving as both predators and prey. Their ecological importance influences the structure and dynamics of marine ecosystems.
edges.label: ecological_significance

edges.c: The lollipop catshark is a little-known species of deep sea catshark, which can be readily identified by its tadpole-like shape with a greatly expanded, rounded head and narrow body. It is a bottom-dwelling shark found on the outer continental shelf and upper continental slope, and it preys on crustaceans and fishes. The species exhibits aplacental viviparity, with females retaining egg cases internally until they hatch.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The lollipop catshark was originally described as Catulus cephalus by Charles Henry Gilbert in 1892, and later placed in the genus Cephalurus by Henry F. Bigelow and William C. Schroeder in 1941. There are potentially other undescribed species of Cephalurus in different locations.
edges.label: originalDescription

edges.c: Cephalurus is thought to form a clade with the genera Asymbolus, Parmaturus, Galeus, and Apristurus, with some disagreement on the interrelationships within this group.
edges.label: phylogeny

edges.c: The lollipop catshark's range extends from the Gulf of California to off the southern Baja peninsula, and it is abundant in benthic areas around the outer continental shelf and upper continental slope at depths of 155–937 m.
edges.label: range

edges.c: It is found in deep-sea basins with low levels of dissolved oxygen, and may possibly also tolerate high temperatures and salinity.

edges.c: Tube-dwelling anemones, also known as ceriantharians, are solitary anthozoans that live buried in soft sediments. They are distinct from sea anemones and belong to their own class, Ceriantharia.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Tube anemones have a crown of tentacles composed of two whorls of distinctly different sized tentacles. The outer whorl consists of large tentacles used for food capture and defence, while the inner tentacles are used for food manipulation and ingestion.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Some species such as Anactinia pelagica are pelagic and not attached to the bottom; they have a gas chamber within the pedal disc, allowing them to float upside down near the surface of the water.

edges.c: Chaetodon humeralis is a species of marine ray-finned fish, a butterflyfish belonging to the family Chaetodontidae. It has an oval disc-like body which is strongly compressed, with a small mouth positioned at the end of a short snout. The body color is white or silvery white with brownish-black bands on the line of the pectoral fin and another running in from the base of the caudal fin. It has a depth range of 2 to 55 metres but is more common between 3 and 12 metres.

edges.c: Members of the fish are primarily found near the ocean floor, along coral reefs, oysters, soft bottoms, and near muddy substrates. Their eating habits revolve around the oceanic floor, where there are occasionally only a few small marine species to be found. As a result, they developed an energy-saving mechanism to allow them to survive on less food. The fish family is a consistent predator. They move slowly enough that their prey is unaware of their existence. In the depths of the ocean floor, they prey on nearly anything, such as small marine fishes that may be part of their diet.

edges.c: Chondrocladia is a genus of carnivorous demosponges of the family Cladorhizidae. Neocladia was long considered a junior synonym, but has recently become accepted as a distinct genus. They are stipitate, with a stalk frequently anchored in the substrate by rhizoids and an egg-shaped body, sometimes with branches that end in inflatable spheres. Fossils assignable to this genus are known since the Pleistocene, less than 2 million years ago. Given its deep-sea habitat, Chondrocladia may well have been around for much longer, perhaps since the Mesozoic, as characteristic spicules almost identical to those of some living Chondrocladia are known from Early Jurassic rocks almost 200 million years old.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Cidarid sea urchins belong to the family Cidaridae in the order Cidaroida. They are characterized by their stout skeleton with thick and hard tests, massive perforated tubercles, and thick, strong, and often very long spines with various shapes.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Massive perforated tubercles, surrounded by a crown of secondary tubercles, but no primary tubercles in the interambulacra regions
edges.label: tubercles

edges.c: Thick, strong and often very long, with various shapes such as thorny spines, fans, clubs, and Christmas trees
edges.label: spines

edges.c: European register of marine species: a check-list of the marine species in Europe and a bibliography of guides to their identification. Collection Patrimoines Naturels, 50: pp. 336–351
edges.label: source

edges.c: Cidaris cidaris is a species of sea urchin with a small central test, long, blunt, widely separated primary spines, and a dense covering of short secondary spines. The primaries are pale grey, tipped with green, and the secondaries are pale green. The sea urchin often has bits of algae, sponge, or other organisms adhering to the spines.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Cidaris cidaris is found in the eastern Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea in deep water on coral, rock, and gravel bottoms. Its range extends from Cape Verde, the Azores, and the Canary Islands northwards to the Faroe Islands and Norway. It is also found on knolls and seamounts at depths down to about 1,800 meters (5,900 feet).
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Cidaris cidaris feeds on sponges, sea fans, and algae.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Cidaris cidaris is one of a number of species of sea urchin that can suffer from bald sea urchin disease.
edges.label: disease

edges.c: Ciliopagurus is a genus of hermit crabs of the family Diogenidae. They are sometimes referred to as the 'left-handed hermit crabs' because the left chela (claw) is enlarged instead of the right. They are found in the Indo-Pacific region and in the eastern Atlantic Ocean.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Diogenidae is a family of hermit crabs. Ciliopagurus belongs to this family.
edges.label: description

edges.c: These sea stars have a flattened and broad pentagonal central disc, with 5 tapering arms. They live between 320 and 3000 meters deep, in the three main oceanic basins.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Worldwide in the three main oceanic basins

edges.c: Barnacles are arthropods with hard calcareous shells. Most are suspension feeders, but some are specialized parasites. Adults are sessile and have existed since at least the mid-Carboniferous. Barnacle geese were once thought to emerge from goose barnacles. They are economically significant as biofouling organisms on ships.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The word "barnacle" is attested in the early 13th century, close to Old French and medieval Latin, denoting the barnacle goose. It was not applied strictly to the arthropod until the 1580s.
edges.label: origin

edges.c: Made of six hard calcareous plates with a lid made of four more plates.
edges.label: carapace

edges.c: Eight pairs of feathery and very long cirri used for filter-feeding.
edges.label: appendages

edges.c: Acorn barnacles attach to the substrate using cement glands, while goose barnacles use a stalk.
edges.label: attachment

edges.c: Minimal blood vascular system, no true heart, and no gills.
edges.label: circulatorySystem

edges.c: Absorbs oxygen from the water through the cirri and the surface of the body.
edges.label: respiratorySystem

edges.c: Mainly sense of touch, with some photoreceptors for detecting light and dark.
edges.label: senses

edges.c: Nauplius and cyprid stages before developing into a mature adult.
edges.label: larvalStages

edges.c: Most barnacles are hermaphroditic and have various mating strategies, including pseudocopulation and spermcasting.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Filter feeders, drawing plankton and detritus into their shells using their cirri.
edges.label: feeding

edges.c: Mostly inhabit shallow waters and intertidal zones, with some species adapted to a rafting lifestyle.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Some species are parasitic castrators of other arthropods, such as crabs.
edges.label: parasitism

edges.c: The oldest definitive fossil barnacle is from the mid-Carboniferous, around 330-320 million years ago. They underwent a significant radiation during the Neogene.
edges.label: fossilRecord

edges.c: Subclass Cirripedia within the infraclass Thecostraca, divided into orders such as Acrothoracica, Rhizocephala, and Thoracica.
edges.label: classification

edges.c: Economically significant as biofouling organisms on man-made structures.
edges.label: economy

edges.c: Some species are consumed as food, including Japanese goose barnacles and Chilean giant barnacles.
edges.label: consumption

edges.c: Inspired the development of adhesives and potentially used for forensic tracking.
edges.label: technology

edges.c: Subject of myths and folklore, including the barnacle goose myth. Also referenced in literature and popular culture.
edges.label: culture

edges.c: Cirroteuthis muelleri is a cirrate octopus species closely related to the genus Cirrothauma within the family Cirroteuthidae. It was the first cirrate octopus species and genus to be scientifically described in 1836. It can reach a maximum length of 400 mm (mantle length 170 mm) and is off white or pale purple in color with brownish-purple inner side of the arms and webs. The head features well-developed eyes with lenses, thin and relatively weak upper and lower beaks, and a gelatinous and fragile body. The arms are nearly equal in length with translucent webs joining the dorsal and ventral sides of the arms together. The suckers and cirri are also notable features of its anatomy.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Cirroteuthis muelleri is found in the Arctic Ocean, northern basins of the Atlantic and Pacific, and may also have unidentified species in the southern hemisphere, such as New Zealand and Australia.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: It is a deep-sea benthopelagic species, swimming or drifting in the immediate above sea bed in cold seas at depths of over 2,000 m. It is particularly found in the seas around Greenland.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Female specimens of Cirroteuthis muelleri were found near the ocean floor at depths between 3,000–3,300 m. Their diet includes small crustaceans and polychaetes, all small benthic or epibenthic prey items. They are known to lay large eggs on the ocean floor.
edges.label: biology

edges.c: Cirrothauma is a genus of deep water octopuses from the cirrate family Cirroteuthidae. The species Cirrothauma are fragile, gelatinous deep-sea octopods with a shell, a moderate saddle, and triangular wings. Their eyes either have lenses, as seen in the species Cirrothauma murrayi or they have reduced eyes without lenses, shown in the other extant species Cirrothauma magna. Both species were placed in Cirrothauma due to the fact that they possess similar shells. These octopuses have been reported to live in all the world's oceans, except for the Southern Ocean.
edges.label: description

edges.c: reported to live in all the world's oceans, except for the Southern Ocean
edges.label: distribution

nodes: New carnivorous sponges and allied species from the Great Australian Bight

edges.c: Cladorhiza is a genus of carnivorous sponges found in oceans around the world. It comprises around 40 species and is the type genus of the family Cladorhizidae.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Species of Cladorhiza occur in a diverse range of shapes, including globular, spherical, conical, tree-like, and bush-like. Many species have a narrow stalk or stem.
edges.label: shapes

edges.c: Most species range from 2 to 12 cm in height, with a few attaining heights of 20 to 40 cm.
edges.label: size

edges.c: Cladorhizidae is a family of carnivorous demosponges found in deep-sea environments worldwide. These sponges are known for their unique feeding structures and predatory behavior, as they capture and consume small animals such as crustaceans.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The Cladorhizidae family is characterized by its branched and bushy growth form, which can reach up to 3 meters in length.
edges.label: growthForm

edges.c: The body is composed of a skeleton made of spicules, which provide structural support and defense against predators.
edges.label: composition

edges.c: The sponge's feeding structures are modified spicules, which can be long and pointed, or branched and club-shaped.
edges.label: feedingStructures

edges.c: Cladorhizidae sponges are typically found on oceanic ridges and seamount systems, where they attach to the seafloor and extend their feeding structures into the water column to capture passing prey.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: They are found in deep-sea environments worldwide.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Cladorhizidae sponges were first described by the British zoologist George Hartwig in 1887.
edges.label: discoveredBy

edges.c: Numerous species have been discovered and described, including several new species in the Southwest Indian Ocean Ridge.
edges.label: recentDiscoveries

edges.c: Due to their predatory nature, Cladorhizidae sponges play an important role in the deep-sea ecosystem by capturing and consuming small animals such as crustaceans.
edges.label: predatoryNature

edges.c: Little is known about the overall impact of Cladorhizidae sponges on the deep-sea ecosystem.
edges.label: impact

edges.c: Cladorhizidae sponges continue to be a subject of fascination for marine biologists, who aim to understand the evolution and ecology of these unique organisms.
edges.label: researchInterest

edges.c: Conservation efforts for deep-sea ecosystems, including those inhabited by Cladorhizidae sponges, are important for preserving the biodiversity and functioning of these systems.
edges.label: conservation

edges.c: Solitary tunicate with a broad base and often appears hemispherical. The two siphons are far apart and conspicuous when expanded. The tunic is thin, but strong, being smooth and shiny. It is often pearly or opaque in appearance, bright red or pinkish-red, but small individuals are often white. Length seldom larger than 3 cm (1.2 in), but can reach up to 5 cm (2 in) with a width of 2.5 cm (1 in). The tunic has a 12.4% organic content, more than half of which is cellulose (tunicin), the rest being protein.
edges.label: morphology

edges.c: Suspension feeder; water is drawn into the body through the buccal siphon by the action of cilia lining the gill slits, food particles are extracted and the water is expelled through the atrial siphon.
edges.label: feedingHabit

edges.c: Hermaphroditic with breeding taking place in summer, fertilisation being external

edges.c: Cnidaria is a phylum of aquatic animals found in both freshwater and marine environments. It includes over 11,000 species, such as jellyfish, hydroids, sea anemones, and corals. Cnidarians have a decentralized nervous system, cnidocytes for envenomation and capturing prey, and bodies consisting of mesoglea sandwiched between two layers of epithelium. They exhibit polymorphism, with both swimming medusae and sessile polyps forms. Cnidarians reproduce sexually and asexually, and their early fossils date back to 580 million years ago.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Specialized cells for envenomation and capturing prey
edges.label: cnidocytes

edges.c: Consists of mesoglea sandwiched between two layers of epithelium
edges.label: body_structure

edges.c: found in shallow waters, polar regions, and even in freshwater
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Important role in coral reefs and in providing fishing grounds

edges.c: Fossils dating back to 580 million years ago, with corals diversified in the Early Ordovician period

edges.c: Molecular phylogenetics show that Cnidaria and Bilateria are more closely related to each other than to Ctenophora
edges.label: family_tree

edges.c: Can cause jellyfish stings, are used as a food source in some cultures, and have economic importance in tourism and aquaculture
edges.label: implications

edges.c: Coelorinchus is a genus of rattail fish. The name derives from Greek κοῖλος (koilos, 'hollow') and ῥύγχος (rhynchos, 'snout').
edges.label: Description

edges.c: Colobonema sericeum is a species of deep-sea hydrozoan in the family Rhopalonematidae that was first described in 1902. This semi-transparent organism is found in the mesopelagic zone, has 32 tentacles, and has a bell diameter of up 45 mm. They are holoplanktonic and never attach to the seafloor as part of their polyp life cycle, but instead have embryos that develop directly into a small, swimming medusae.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Comatulida is an order of crinoids, also known as feather stars, that mostly do not have a stalk as adults. Members of this order are characterized by having the oral surface with the mouth facing upwards and surrounded by five often divided rays with feathery pinnules. They are found in tropical and temperate waters, living on the seabed and on reefs.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Pentamerous symmetry as adults, bilateral symmetry in larvae. Endoskeleton made of articulated calcareous plates. Body shape is a cup (calyx) with a lid (tegmen) containing the mouth and an anus. They have five long, often branched, rays attached round the edge of the tegmen, each further subdivided into branchlets (pinnules). Comatulids are suspension feeders with dioecious reproduction.
edges.label: characteristics

edges.c: Comatulids are mostly sedentary, but some can move across the seabed or swim with their arms. They are suspension feeders, extending their arms to gather plankton. Reproduction is dioecious, with specialized pinnules producing gametes. After several larval stages, they settle on the seabed and anchor themselves with a stalk, which breaks at metamorphosis.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Unappetising to most predators, but preyed on by some fish, with the ability to regenerate lost arms or visceral mass. Many other invertebrates live as commensals among the rays of crinoids.
edges.label: predation

edges.c: Comatulidae is a family of comatulid crinoids, consisting of 93 to 95 species distributed in 21 genera. It is the second most diversified family of crinoids behind Antedonidae, representing approximately 1/6th of known crinoid species. The family contains mostly large species of shallow tropical feather stars, particularly in the Indo-Pacific.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Conger oligoporus is a tropical, marine eel known from Hawaii and Guam in the eastern central and western central Pacific Ocean. It was described by Robert H. Kanazawa in 1958. It dwells at a depth range of 2–507 metres, leads a benthic lifestyle, and inhabits crevices of hard substrata. It feeds predominantly on finfish.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Marine, inhabits crevices of hard substrata
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Copepods are a group of small crustaceans found in almost every freshwater and saltwater habitat. They have diverse ecological roles, including planktonic, benthic, and parasitic lifestyles. They are important components of aquatic food webs and contribute to the global carbon cycle.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Most copepods feed on phytoplankton and detritus, while some are predatory or parasitic
edges.label: feeding
