edges.c: Corallimorpharia is an order of marine cnidarians closely related to stony or reef building corals (Scleractinia). They occur in both temperate and tropical climates, although they are mostly tropical. They resemble stony corals but lack a stony skeleton, and are closely related to stony corals based on morphological and molecular evidence.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Corallimorpharians occur in a wide range of marine habitats and can be associated with phase shifts in coral reef ecosystems.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Corallimorphus is a genus of colonial anthozoans similar in appearance to sea anemones and in body format to scleractinian stony corals. These animals are cnidarians in the family Corallimorphidae. Members of the genus live off the Pacific coast of the US.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Red corals grow on rocky seabottom with low sedimentation, typically in dark environments—either in the depths or in dark caverns or crevices. The original species, C. rubrum (formerly Gorgonia nobilis), is found mainly in the Mediterranean Sea. It grows at depths from 10 to 300 meters below sea level, although the shallower of these habitats have been largely depleted by harvesting.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Red corals have the shape of small leafless bushes and can grow up to a meter in height. Their valuable skeleton is composed of intermeshed spicules of hard calcium carbonate, colored in shades of red by carotenoid pigments. In living specimens, the skeletal branches are overlaid with soft bright red integument, from which numerous retractable white polyps protrude.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The hard skeleton of red coral branches is naturally matte, but can be polished to a glassy shine. It exhibits a range of warm reddish pink colors from pale pink to deep red. Owing to its intense and permanent coloration and glossiness, precious coral skeletons have been harvested since antiquity for decorative use. Coral jewellery has been found in ancient Egyptian and prehistoric European burials, and continues to be made to the present day.
edges.label: description

edges.c: At the beginning of the 1st millennium, there was significant trade in coral between the Mediterranean and India, where it was highly prized as a substance believed to be endowed with mysterious sacred properties.
edges.label: description

edges.c: In Hindu astrology red coral is associated with the planet Mars and used for pleasing Mars. It should be worn on the ring finger. Amongst the Yoruba and Bini peoples of West Africa, red precious coral jewellery are signifiers of high social rank, and are worn as a result by titled kings and chieftains.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Intensive fishing, particularly in shallow waters, has damaged this species along the Mediterranean coastline, where colonies at depths of less than 50 meters are much diminished. Fishing and now climate change threaten their persistence.
edges.label: description

nodes: Tree of Life web project: Cranchia scabra

edges.c: Cranchia scabra is a species of glass squid. It is the only species in the genus, and is fairly small (about 150 millimeters (5.9 in)). The mantle is covered by large, multi-pointed cartilagenous tubercles. When disturbed, the squid often pulls its head and arms into the mantle cavity and folds its fins tightly against the mantle to form a turgid ball. The tubercules, presumably, provide some type of protection, but it is unclear what predators are affected and how. In addition, the squid may ink into the mantle cavity, making the ball opaque. This was thought to be an aberrant behavior due to the stress and confinement of shipboard aquaria, until the same inking behavior was seen in cranchiids from submersibles. The function of this behavior is unknown. The genus contains bioluminescent species.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Ctenophora comprise a phylum of marine invertebrates known as comb jellies, notable for the groups of cilia they use for swimming. They are the largest animals to swim with the help of cilia and range in size from a few millimeters to 1.5 m. They have a wide range of body forms and are primarily predators, preying on microscopic larvae, rotifers, and small crustaceans. Fossils of ctenophores have been found in lagerstätten dating back to the early Cambrian, about 525 million years ago.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Found in most marine environments, from polar waters to the tropics and from the surface to ocean depths of more than 7000 meters. Found near coasts and in mid-ocean. No ctenophores have been found in freshwater.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Ctenophores are primarily predators, feeding on zooplankton and other small marine organisms. Some are preyed upon by jellyfish, turtles, and other organisms.
edges.label: preyAndPredators

edges.c: Fossils of ctenophores have been found in lagerstätten, dating back to the early Cambrian period, about 525 million years ago. Early fossils resembled modern species but had more comb rows. There are also fossils suggesting a sessile form similar to Vendobionta with cilia on branches, thought to be related to the origin of ctenophores.
edges.label: fossilRecord

edges.c: The phylogenetic relationship of ctenophores to other animals has been debated, with some studies suggesting they are the sister lineage to all other animals and others suggesting they are sister to Cnidaria, Placozoa, and Bilateria.

edges.c: In ancient Roman religion, birth and childhood deities were thought to care for every aspect of conception, pregnancy, childbirth, and child development. The belief in these deities reflects the high value Romans placed on family, tradition, and the compatibility of the sexes.
edges.label: Introduction

edges.c: In antiquity, childbirth was a life-threatening experience for both the woman and her newborn, with infant mortality as high as 30 or 40 percent. Rites of passage pertaining to birth and death had several parallel aspects, and maternal death was common.
edges.label: Childbirth

edges.c: Several ritual practices surrounding childbirth may be characterized as anxious superstitions, but the religious aura surrounding childbirth reflects the high value Romans placed on family, tradition, and compatibility of the sexes.
edges.label: Ritual Practices

edges.c: Deepstaria enigmatica is a rarely seen giant jellyfish with a wide, thin, transparent bell and lacks tentacles. It is found in Antarctic and near-Antarctic seas and has been spotted at depths of 600–1,750 metres. It moves through peristalsis and has a geometric mesh pattern throughout its bell for capturing prey.

edges.c: Deepstaria reticulum is a jellyfish with a wide, fan-like bell that is often a deep purple color. It has a small cluster of tentacles under the bell, which are loaded with stinging, venomous barbs. At the largest, they grow to about 0.7 meters long. Unlike D. enigmatica, the bell of D. reticulum is spread wide, like a thin, translucent bed sheet. The digestive tract consists of a highly branched network of canal systems spread over the entire length of the body.

edges.c: Demosponges are the most diverse class in the phylum Porifera, with nearly 8,800 species worldwide. They have a soft body that covers a hard, often massive skeleton made of calcium carbonate, predominantly leuconoid in structure. Their skeletons are made of spicules consisting of fibers of the protein spongin, the mineral silica, or both. They reproduce sexually and asexually, and some species have a long lifespan of 500–1,000 years. Demosponges are the only extant organisms that methylate sterols at the 26-position, and their dense skeletons can provide data about ocean temperature and salinity.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The only order of freshwater sponges, split from the marine sponges about 311 million years ago in the Late Carboniferous.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The first demosponges may have appeared during the Precambrian deposits at the end of the Cryogenian 'Snowball Earth' period. Fossilized steroids called steranes provide indirect evidence of their presence. The earliest Demospongiae fossil was discovered in the lower Cambrian.
edges.label: ancientHistory

edges.c: The Systema Porifera (2002) book organized extant Demospongiae into 14 orders. However, molecular and morphological evidence led to a revision of the classification to include three subclasses: Verongimorpha, Keratosa, and Heteroscleromorpha.
edges.label: firstClassification

edges.c: Spermatocytes and oocytes develop from choanocytes and archeocytes, respectively. The resulting swimming larvae enter a canal of the central cavity and are expelled with the exhalant current.
edges.label: sexualReproduction

edges.c: Includes budding and the formation of gemmules. Gemmules are found in the freshwater family Spongillidae and are capable of surviving harsh conditions.
edges.label: asexualReproduction

edges.c: The most economically important group of demosponges to humans are the bath sponges, which are harvested by divers and grown commercially. They are bleached and marketed; the spongin gives the sponge its softness.
edges.label: economicImportance

edges.c: Dendronotus patricki is a species of sea slug, a dendronotid nudibranch, a shell-less marine gastropod mollusc in the family Dendronotidae. It is a translucent species with no surface markings and a reddish-brown hue to the body. It can grow to at least 25 mm in length. There is a small amount of opaque white pigment at the tips of the dorsal appendages, velar appendages, and rhinophore sheath papillae.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Dendronotus patricki was described from a whalefall in Monterey Canyon, California at a depth of 1820 m. It was also observed on video from another whalefall in Santa Cruz Basin at a depth of 1676 m.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Dendronotus patricki was found crawling on a muddy seabed at depths of around 1800 m. Its stomach contents included structures thought to be nematocysts, and it is possible that it feeds on burrowing cerianthid anemones as does Dendronotus iris.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Found at depths down to about 900 metres (3,000 ft)

edges.c: Diatoms are a group of algae found in oceans, waterways, and soils. They play a significant role in producing oxygen, taking in silicon, and contributing to the Earth's biomass. They are unicellular organisms and are known for their silica cell walls. Diatoms are classified as a type of plankton called phytoplankton and are used to monitor past and present environmental conditions. They are also widely used in various industrial applications and have potential uses in nanotechnology.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Diatoms generate about 20 to 50 percent of the oxygen produced on the planet each year.
edges.label: oxygenProduction

edges.c: Diatoms constitute nearly half of the organic material found in the oceans.
edges.label: biomassContribution

edges.c: They take in over 6.7 billion tonnes of silicon each year from the waters they inhabit.
edges.label: siliconAbsorption

edges.c: Diatoms are generally 2 to 200 micrometers in size, with a few larger species.
edges.label: sizeRange

edges.c: They occur either as solitary cells or in colonies, which can take the shape of ribbons, fans, zigzags, or stars.
edges.label: shapes

edges.c: They are surrounded by a cell wall made of silica, called a frustule. These frustules produce structural coloration, prompting them to be described as 'jewels of the sea' and 'living opals.'
edges.label: uniqueFeature

edges.c: Movement in diatoms primarily occurs passively as a result of both ocean currents and wind-induced water turbulence.
edges.label: passiveMovement

edges.c: They are estimated to be responsible for about half of photosynthesis in the global oceans.
edges.label: contributionToPhotosynthesis

edges.c: They play a crucial role in the biological carbon pump, transferring surface carbon to the deep ocean and sequestering atmospheric CO2 for extended periods.
edges.label: roleInCarbonCycle

edges.c: Diatoms and their shells, known as diatomite or diatomaceous earth, are used for fine polishing and liquid filtration. Diatomite is considered to be a natural nanomaterial and has numerous industrial applications.
edges.label: diatomite

edges.c: The first illustrations of diatoms are found in an article from 1703 in Transactions of the Royal Society showing unmistakable drawings of Tabellaria. The first formally identified diatom, the colonial Bacillaria paxillifera, was described in 1783 by Danish naturalist Otto Friedrich Müller.
edges.label: discovery

edges.label: description

edges.c: Didemnidae is a family of colonial tunicates in the order Aplousobranchia. These marine animals are found in shallow water on the seabed. Members of this family have small zooids that form encrusting colonies. The body of each zooid is divided into a thorax and abdomen.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Diogenidae is a family of hermit crabs known for their left-handed chela enlargement, comprising 429 extant species and 46 extinct species. It is the second-largest family of marine hermit crabs.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Dofleinia armata is one of Australia's largest species of anemone. It can grow to 20 cm in diameter, with tentacles up to 50 cm long. The base of this species is broad, the column smooth, with a broad, flat oral disc. It has long inner tentacles which are a minimum of double the size of the outer tentacles. The surface of the tentacles end in a tip that is somewhat swollen. The tentacles are either cream, brown, or plain, and are striped. They have a surface that is scale-like and are often observed curling into ball shapes that hide the mouth. It is able to expand its body and tentacles due to a well-developed hydrostatic system.
edges.label: description

edges.c: This species is known to live in the tropical waters of Australia as far south as Perth, Western Australia. It is also known to occur in the Philippines and Indonesia.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The species lives at depths of up to 20 metres in the intertidal zone on sloping, sheltered reefs, as well as in mangroves. It may be found in fine silt or mud.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The sting of Dofleinia armata presents a danger to humans. Injuries resulting from contact with this species are considered very painful, and can take several months to heal.
edges.label: dangerToHumans

edges.c: Transparent, gelatinous barrel-shaped animals, usually less than one centimetre long. They move in jerks by contracting the circular bands of muscle in their body wall sharply.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Complex life cycle with alternating sexual and asexual phases. They use a net of mucus strands to efficiently trap phytoplankton floating past. They grow fast and multiply rapidly, with a single animal capable of forming thousands of new individuals in a few days. They sometimes form dense swarms with up to 500 individuals per square metre.
edges.label: lifeCycle

edges.c: Doliolida are small marine animals with barrel-shaped bodies, featuring two wide siphons and circular muscle strands. They are filter feeders and free-swimming plankton, primarily found in tropical oceans. Their complicated life cycle includes sexual and asexual generations, and they can produce an astonishing number of progeny. Doliolids have natural enemies, such as the copepod Sapphirina nigromaculata.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Doliolids alternate through sexual and asexual generations. The sexual generation consists of individuals featuring eight muscle bands, each having male or female gonads. Fertilized eggs produce asexual individuals with nine muscle bands and two stalks, which produce mature progeny asexually.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The opalescent inshore squid, or market squid, is a small squid in the family Loliginidae. It is a myopsid squid with corneas over its eyes. The species lives in the eastern Pacific Ocean from Mexico's Baja California peninsula to Alaska, United States, and can be found within a range of 200 miles off the coast.

edges.c: The Echinothurioida are an order of sea urchins in the class Echinoidea. They are distinguished by their flexible test and hollow spines, and are nearly all deep-sea dwellers.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Echinothurioids have regular tests (shells) with 10 columns of plates. These plates are fused in groups of three with a central primary plate and a half plate on either side, making the test flexible.
edges.label: test

edges.c: The primary tubercles which articulate with the spines are each perforated by a hole and the spines are hollow. The primary spines are usually long and are used to support the test and in locomotion. In many species, the secondary spines are tipped with poison glands.
edges.label: spines

edges.c: The membrane around the mouth contains only simple plates, and the mouthparts, known as the Aristotle's lantern, have simple plates and grooved teeth.
edges.label: mouthparts

edges.c: The gills are relatively small, and in many species, entirely absent.
edges.label: gills

edges.c: Echinothurioids are nearly all found on the seabed at abyssal depths, but some species may be found in shallow water.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Little is known of their feeding habits, but examination of their stomach contents suggests they eat detritus, mostly in the form of algal fragments.
edges.label: feeding habits

edges.c: Their reproduction is relatively unstudied, but some members of the group produce eggs with large yolks which at first rise towards the surface and later sink again. The bilaterally symmetrical larva, called an echinopluteus, is planktonic and may not feed, relying on its yolk for nourishment before descending to the seabed and undergoing metamorphosis.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: For many years, echinothurioids were believed to be extinct, being only known from fossils. The earliest known echinothurioid was Pelanechinus, dating back to the Middle to Late Jurassic. The earliest crown group example was Echinothuria, which came from the Upper Cretaceous of southern England.
edges.label: fossils

edges.c: As sardine populations declined in the Pacific during the 1940s and 50's, fish packers in America started canning the more abundant local anchovies. Total hauls increased over this time from 960 tons in 1946 to 9,464 tons in 1947 and peaking at almost 43,000 tons in 1953. From 1949 to 1955, they were restricted for all uses but bait fish in California. In 2010, reported American hauls totaled 2,100 metric tons. Most Californian anchovies today are fished for use in animal feed and as bait fish.

edges.c: Enteroctopus is a genus of generally temperate octopuses characterized by their large size and distinct longitudinal wrinkles or folds dorsally and laterally on their bodies. Their heads are distinctly narrower than the mantle width. The hectocotylus of the males in this genus, found on the third right arm, is long and narrow in comparison with other genera in the family Octopodidae. They have large, paddle-like papillae instead of the more conical papillae in other octopus genera.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Species in the genus Enteroctopus are restricted to the temperate areas of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. E. dofleini is found in the Northern Hemisphere, and the other three species are found in the Southern Hemisphere.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The world's largest octopus based on direct measurements of a 71 kilograms (157 pounds) individual, weighed live. This octopus had a total length near to 3.5 metres (11 feet).
edges.label: record

edges.c: substantially smaller, with E. megalocyathus having an average mass of 4 kilograms (8.8 pounds) and reaching a total length of 1.0 metre (3.3 feet). E. magnificus reaches a total length of around 1.5 metres (5 feet).

edges.c: The giant Pacific octopus is a large marine cephalopod with a spatial distribution encompassing much of the coastal North Pacific. edges.c: The Etmopteridae, commonly known as lantern sharks, are a family of sharks in the order Squaliformes. They inhabit deep waters worldwide and comprise 45 species distributed among five genera.

edges.c: Eulimidae is a family of very small parasitic sea snails, marine gastropod mollusks in the superfamily Vanikoroidea. These small parasitic snails live on (or in some cases in) the bodies of echinoderms such as sea cucumbers, sea urchins, sea stars, etc. All species lack a radula, in most cases possessing a proboscis which they extend into their host's body cavity in order to feed.

edges.c: Chirostyloidea is an anomuran superfamily with squat lobster-like representatives. It comprises the three families Chirostylidae, Eumunididae, and Kiwaidae. Although representatives of Chirostyloidea are superficially similar to galatheoid squat lobsters, they are more closely related to Lomisoidea and Aegloidea, together forming the clade Australopoda. No fossils can be confidently assigned to the Chirostyloidea, although Pristinaspina may belong either in the family Kiwaidae or Chirostylidae.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The largest genus of krill, placed in the family Euphausiidae. It includes 31 known species.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Media related to Euphausia at Wikimedia Commons
edges.label: mediaLinks

edges.c: Krill are small and exclusively marine crustaceans of the order Euphausiacea, found in all the world's oceans.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Krill are considered an important trophic level connection at the bottom of the food chain, serving as the main food source for many larger animals including whales, seals, penguins, seabirds, squid, and fish.
edges.label: importance

edges.c: Krill occur worldwide in all oceans, with many individual species having endemic or neritic distributions.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Krill are filter feeders, feeding primarily on phytoplankton, particularly diatoms. They are mostly omnivorous, but some species are carnivorous, preying on small zooplankton and fish larvae.
edges.label: feeding

edges.c: Krill are preyed upon by various animals including fish, penguins, seals, and baleen whales.
edges.label: predation

edges.c: Krill are fished in the Southern Ocean and in the waters around Japan, with the majority of the catch used for aquaculture and aquarium feeds, bait in sport fishing, or in the pharmaceutical industry. They are also used for human consumption in Japan, the Philippines, and Russia, as well as in traditional dishes such as camarones in Spain and Philippines.
edges.label: commercial_harvesting

edges.c: Krill are decapod crustaceans with a chitinous external skeleton, compound eyes, two antennae, and several pairs of thoracic legs. They also possess bioluminescent organs called photophores.
edges.label: physical_characteristics

edges.c: Most krill are about 1–2 centimetres (0.4–0.8 in) long as adults, with some species growing to sizes of 6–15 centimetres (2.4–5.9 in).
edges.label: size

edges.c: Krill hatch and go through several larval stages before reaching maturity, and they reproduce by spawning fertilized eggs into the water or carrying the eggs attached to the female.
edges.label: lifecycle

edges.c: During the mating season, the male deposits a sperm sack at the female's genital opening, and females can carry several thousand eggs in their ovary.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Most krill are swarming animals, with swarms varying in size and density by species and region, serving as a defensive mechanism against predators.
edges.label: swarming

edges.c: Krill typically follow a diurnal vertical migration, spending the day at greater depths and rising during the night toward the surface.
edges.label: migrations

edges.c: Disturbances in the krill population can have far-reaching effects on the ecosystem, as demonstrated by a decline in krill population leading to cascading impacts on other species.
edges.label: predation_impact

edges.c: Antarctic krill play a prominent role in the Southern Ocean by cycling nutrients and serving as a key element in the Antarctic food web.
edges.label: biogeochemical_cycles

edges.c: Krill have been harvested for human and domesticated animal consumption since the 19th century, with large-scale fishing operations developing in the late 1960s. The total fishing yield has increased, with major countries involved in harvesting including Norway, the Republic of Korea, and China.
edges.label: harvesting

edges.c: Krill have inspired robotic platforms to study their locomotion and find design solutions for underwater robots.
edges.label: bio_inspired_robotics

edges.c: Florometra serratissima is a species of crinoid or feather star found off the Pacific coast of North America. It has a stalk, a calyx, and a set of arms with jointed appendages known as pinnules, giving it a feather-like appearance. It measures about 25 cm across when its arms are fully extended, and is reddish-brown in color. Juveniles have a long stalk.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The Forcipulatida is an order of sea stars containing three families and 49 genera. They are known for their distinctive pedicellariae and tend to have more robust bodies compared to other sea star groups. Some well-known species in this order include the common starfish (Asterias rubens). They can be commonly found from North Carolina in the United States to Santos in Brazil.
edges.label: description

edges.c: A 2020 study involving phylogenetic analysis and scanning electron microscopy of the skeleton and ossicles of taxa from the superorder Forcipulatacea recovered Asteriidae, Stichasteridae, Zoroasteridae, and Brisingida as monophyletic.

edges.c: Fritillaria is a genus of perennial herbaceous bulbiferous geophytes in the lily family (Liliaceae), characterized by nodding flowers, perianths campanulate with nectarial pits at the base of the tepal, large genome size, and close genetic relation to lilies. The genus has about 130–140 species divided among eight subgenera.
edges.label: genusDescription

edges.c: Fritillaria meleagris, also known as snake's head fritillary, is the type species of the genus. It has solitary, nodding, bell-shaped flowers and is native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It is an ornamental garden plant and is commercially important in horticulture.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Fritillaria imperialis, also called crown imperial, is known for its large genome size. It is endangered due to over-harvesting and is native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Fritillaria persica has naked bulbs with many scales and is known for its use in traditional medicine. It is endangered due to enthusiastic picking.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Tunicate, consisting of tightly packed fleshy scales with a translucent tunic, although some species have naked bulbs with many scales and loosely attached bulbils.
edges.label: bulbs

edges.c: Solitary, nodding, bell-shaped, usually actinomorphic, with six tepals in two free whorls, and large nectaries. The flowers are usually pollinated by wasps or bumblebees.
edges.label: flowers

edges.c: Most fritillaries contain poisonous steroidal alkaloids, and some species may even be deadly if ingested in quantity.
edges.label: toxicity

edges.c: Found in most temperate zones of the Northern Hemisphere, with centres of diversity in Turkey and the Zagros Mountains of Iran. Some species are widely introduced.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Fritillaria species are popular as ornamental garden plants and are commercially available. They are usually grown from dormant bulbs planted in Autumn.
edges.label: horticulture

edges.c: Many species of Fritillaria have been used in traditional Chinese medicine for over 2,000 years and are of significant commercial value, although over-harvesting has led to endangerment.
edges.label: traditionalMedicine

edges.c: A number of Fritillaria species are endangered due to over-harvesting, habitat fragmentation, over-grazing, and international demand for herbals.
edges.label: conservation

edges.c: Gammaridea is a suborder of the order Amphipoda, comprising small, shrimp-like crustaceans. Traditionally, it encompassed the majority of amphipod species, including almost all freshwater amphipods and many marine species. However, it is now considered paraphyletic and has undergone significant taxonomic revision.

edges.c: Gobiidae is a family of bony fish with more than 2,000 species in over 200 genera. Most gobiid fish are small, with some of the smallest vertebrates in the world. They are important as prey species for commercially important fish and are also popular as aquarium fish. Their distinctive feature is the fused pelvic fins that form a disc-shaped sucker, allowing them to adhere to rocks, corals, and aquarium surfaces.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Gobiidae are found in tropical and temperate near shore-marine, brackish, and freshwater environments worldwide.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Gobies are primarily bottom-dwellers, living in burrows, caves, coral reefs, and seagrass meadows.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Endemic to the Ponto-Caspian region, these gobies have fused pelvic fins and elongated dorsal and anal fins. Examples include tadpole gobies, monkey gobies, and bighead gobies.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Known as true gobies, this subfamily is the most widespread and diverse among gobiids, containing around 2000 species and 150 genera.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Most gobies feed on small invertebrates, while larger species may eat other fish or planktonic algae.
edges.label: feedingHabits

edges.c: Gobiids attach their eggs to a substrate, with the male guarding and fanning the eggs until they hatch. Some species are adapted to freshwater environments, and larvae may be carried downstream to brackish waters or the sea.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Many gobiids live in male-female pairs and construct burrows for shelter and spawning. Burrow maintenance is a cooperative behavior, with males primarily caring for the eggs.
edges.label: burrowConstruction

edges.c: Some male gobies exhibit sneaking behavior during reproduction, fertilizing eggs of paired females while the paired male cares for the eggs.
edges.label: kleptogamy

edges.c: Certain gobiid species can change their sexes, often from female to male, depending on the group dynamics and mating opportunities.
edges.label: sexChange

edges.c: Some gobiids can remember landmarks within short distances and use them for navigation in their habitats.
edges.label: navigation

edges.c: Gobiids have symbiotic relationships with burrowing shrimps, where both parties benefit from the association.
edges.label: withBurrowingShrimps

edges.c: Some gobiids act as cleaner fish, removing parasites from the skin, fins, mouth, and gills of larger fish, benefiting from a continuous food supply.
edges.label: withLargerFish

edges.c: Gobiids have commercial importance in Russia, Ukraine, and Italy, especially species like round goby, monkey goby, toad goby, and grass goby.
edges.label: fishing

edges.c: Several gobiid species are kept in aquariums, with popular marine species including Randall's shrimp goby and the neon goby.
edges.label: aquariumTrade

edges.c: The Gonatidae, also known as armhook squid, are a family of moderately sized squid. The family contains about 19 species in three genera, widely distributed and plentiful in cold boreal waters of the Pacific Ocean. They are pelagic and associated with the continental shelf, and may roam as deep as 4,500 m or more, depending on the species.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Armhook squid are characterized by the suckers of their arms, which are arranged in four rows (series) rather than the typical count of two. In most species, the arm's two mesial rows of suckers have been modified into hooks, and the tentacular clubs possess an enlarged central hook, with or without several smaller hooks. Species of the genus Gonatus lack tentacles as adults. The fiery armhook squid (Gonatus pyros) is the only species that possesses photophores located on the ventral periphery of the eyes. They have muscular, cylindrical bodies with very soft, reddish to purplish-brown skin. The arms are thick and capable, and the fins vary in shape and size.
edges.label: characteristics

edges.c: These squid range in size from 11 to 40 cm, with most species being 25 cm or less. Females are somewhat larger than males.
edges.label: size

edges.c: These squid are thought to undertake diel migration, staying in the depths by day and ascending to the upper layers of the water column by night to feed.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Little is known about the reproductive cycle of armhook squid. Most species deposit eggs on the sea floor, then leave the eggs to hatch on their own. Some species, like Gonatus onyx, have been observed dragging a membrane sack containing developing eggs.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Cetaceans, large seabirds, seals, and large fish are known predators of armhook squid. Cannibalism also occurs within the family.
edges.label: predators

edges.c: Two series of hooks along midline of oral surface
edges.label: Arms

edges.c: Gonatopsis borealis is a medium-sized squid found in the North Pacific Ocean. It is a member of the family Gonatidae and is abundant in cold temperate waters. The species exhibits three morphs: large-bodied, slender-bodied, and small-bodied. It is an important prey species for many commercially important fish and marine mammals.

edges.c: The Gonatus Onyx, also known as the Clawed arm hook squid or the Black-eyed squid, is a smaller-sized squid with a characteristic black eye and two arms with clawed hooks. It is primarily found in the northern Pacific Ocean, from Japan to California, often at deeper depths but rising during the day to feed. The mantle size can reach up to 18cm, and it exhibits sexual dimorphism in mantle size with females maturing faster and growing larger than males.

edges.c: Goniasteridae are middle-sized sea stars with a characteristic double range of marginal plates bordering the disk and arms. Most of them have five arms, often short and triangular, around a broad central disc; many species are pentagonal or subpentagonal, covered densely with granular, seed-like protuberances. The aboral face is often covered with tiny spines resembling paxillae. Pedicellariae are often valvate, and the gonads are located at the interradius.

edges.c: Gorgoniidae is a family of soft corals with retractable polyps and stems composed of an axis of the protein gorgonin surrounding a narrow, hollow, cross-chambered central core. The family is polyphyletic, and its members are primarily distinguished by the degree and type of spiculation, branching patterns, and overall colony morphology. Species within this family are mostly native to warm waters around the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of America, with some genera having a more widespread distribution including the temperate eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean Sea.

edges.c: Sea angels are small free-swimming sea slugs classified into six different families within the clade Gymnosomata. They are pelagic opisthobranchs in the mollusc clade Heterobranchia, with a geographic range from polar regions to equatorial seas.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The foot has developed into wing-like flapping appendages, and they discard their embryonic shells a few days after hatching. Their lack of a heavy shell allows them to hover and maneuver more efficiently.

edges.c: Sea angels are carnivorous, feeding on their fellow pteropods, the Thecosomata, and their hunting strategies vary from ambush predation to active pursuit. They use their wing-like parapodia to propel through the water column.

edges.c: They are simultaneous hermaphrodites with internal fertilization. After fertilization, they release gelatinous egg masses, and their embryonic shells are lost within a few days after hatching.

edges.c: Sea angels are a clade within the order Pteropoda, arranged under the superfamily Clionoidea and superfamily Hydromyloidea.

edges.c: The seven-arm octopus, Haliphron atlanticus, is one of the largest known species of octopus. It is named for the appearance of having seven arms due to the male's coiled hectocotylus, though it actually has eight arms like other octopuses. It belongs to the monotypic genus Haliphron in the family Alloposidae within the suborder Incirrata of the order Octopoda.

edges.c: Haliscera bigelowi is a species of deep sea hydrozoan of the family Halicreatidae. The umbrella is 15–17 mm wide, 9–10 mm high, almost hemispherical, with very thick, hemispherical apex. Adults have about 96 marginal tentacles, about 12 marginal tentacles and 3 statocysts in each octant, and thickening of marginal cnidocyst tissue less pronounced than in H. conica. The gonads are broadly oval, about 2/5 as long as radial canals, and located slightly nearer manubrium than bell margin.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Umbrella up to 18 mm, with very thick, bluntly conical projection; 64-72 marginal tentacles in adults; 8-9 tentacles and 2 statocysts in each octant; the base of tentacles surrounded by broad thickening of marginal cnidocyst tissue; gonads oval, well separated from manubrium in the middle portion of 8 broad radial canals.

nodes: Includes shelled marine and freshwater species.
Almost all marine species, some shelled and some not. The internal organs of the opisthobranchs have undergone detorsion (unwinding of the viscera that were twisted during torsion).

Includes the majority of land snails and slugs, many freshwater snails, and a small number of marine species. The mantle cavity of the Pulmonata is modified into an air-breathing organ. They are also characterized by detorsion and a symmetrically-arranged nervous system. The pulmonates almost always lack an operculum and are hermaphroditic.
Dinapoli A. (2009). Phylogeny and Evolution of the Heterobranchia (Mollusca, Gastropoda). Thesis, Frankfurt am Main, 176 pp. PDF.

Dinapoli A.; Klussmann-Kolb A. (2010). 'The long way to diversity – Phylogeny and evolution of the Heterobranchia (Mollusca: Gastropoda)'. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution. 55 (1): 60–76. doi:10.1016/j.ympev.2009.09.019. PMID 19778622.

edges.c: The sixgill stingray is a flabby, heavy-bodied fish with a unique trait of having six pairs of gill slits rather than the typical five. It has a rounded pectoral fin disc, a long, triangular, and flexible snout filled with gelatinous substance, and lacks dermal denticles. It grows up to 1.7 m (5.6 ft) long, with a brownish upper body and white underside.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Benthic in nature, the sixgill stingray is found over upper continental slopes and seamounts at depths of 500–1,120 m (1,640–3,670 ft) in scattered locations across the Indo-Pacific from South Africa to Hawaii.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Discovered and described as a new species in 1980 by Phillip Heemstra and Margaret Smith, who placed it in its own family (Hexatrygonidae).
edges.label: discovery

edges.c: Although several species of sixgill stingrays have been historically described, current evidence suggests they may represent variations in a single, widespread species.
edges.label: speciesVariation

edges.c: Phylogenetic studies using morphological and genetic data have shown that the sixgill stingray is the most basal member of the stingray lineage.
edges.label: phylogeny

edges.c: Hippasteria is one of 70 genera of sea stars in the diverse family Goniasteridae. These sea stars are regular, five-armed starfishes, with a large and flattened central disc. Most of the species in this genus live in deep seas, where they seem to be predators of deep sea coral and cnidarians.

edges.c: Most species in the genus live in deep seas
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Hippasteria muscipula is a deep-sea sea star in the genus Hippasteria, family Goniasteridae. It is a regular, five-armed sea star with a large and flattened central disc. The body is covered by short and stout spines, and it is characterized by big, fly-trap like pedicellariae. It is a rather big species, growing up to 30 cm across. It is a predator of deep sea coral and other cnidarians, observed climbing on corals in order to feed. The species was unknown to science until 2014 and has been observed in the depths of the Pacific Ocean, in locations such as Hawaii, New Caledonia, and New Zealand, between 425 and 1500 meters deep.
edges.label: description

edges.c: This species lives in the depths of Pacific Ocean, and has been recorded in Hawaii, New Caledonia, and New Zealand, between 425 and 1500 meters deep.
edges.label: habitat

edges.label: bibliography

edges.c: Leeches are segmented parasitic or predatory worms that comprise the subclass Hirudinea within the phylum Annelida. They are closely related to the oligochaetes, which include the earthworm, and like them, have soft, muscular segmented bodies that can lengthen and contract.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The majority of leeches live in freshwater habitats.
edges.label: freshwater

edges.c: Some species can be found in terrestrial environments.
edges.label: terrestrial

edges.c: Best-known species feed on blood, such as the medicinal leech Hirudo medicinalis, which secretes the peptide hirudin to prevent blood clotting.
edges.label: hematophagous

edges.c: A minority of leech species are predatory, mostly preying on small invertebrates.
edges.label: predatory

edges.c: Eggs are enclosed in cocoons, usually attached to an underwater surface for aquatic species, or concealed under logs or buried in damp soil for terrestrial species. Some species exhibit parental care by brooding the eggs or carrying the young.
edges.label: cocoon_enclosure

edges.c: Leeches have been used in medicine from ancient times until the 19th century for bloodletting and are still used in modern medicine for treating joint diseases, extremity vein diseases, and in microsurgery. Hirudin, a component of leech saliva, is used as an anticoagulant drug to treat blood-clotting disorders.
edges.label: historical

edges.c: The oldest leech fossils are from the middle Permian period around 266 million years ago.
edges.label: oldest_fossils

edges.c: Leeches have segmented bodies with suckers at both ends, muscular body walls, and reduced coelomic cavities.
edges.label: morphology

edges.c: Leeches are hermaphrodites, with female gonopores, nine pairs of testes, and other reproductive organs.
edges.label: reproductive_organs

edges.c: Leeches have pigment spot ocelli, sensory papillae, and can detect touch, vibration, movement, and chemicals secreted by their hosts.
edges.label: sensory_organs

edges.c: Leech bites are generally alarming rather than dangerous, though a small percentage of people have severe allergic or anaphylactic reactions. Leeches have been historically used for bloodletting and are still used in modern medicine.
edges.label: bites

edges.c: Exposure to synthetic estrogen from contraceptive medicines in freshwater ecosystems can affect leeches' reproductive systems.
edges.label: water_pollution

edges.c: Histioteuthis is a genus of squid in the family Histioteuthidae known for its unique eye structure, with one eye being normal-sized, round, blue and sunken, and the other being at least twice the diameter, tubular, yellow-green, upward facing, and bulging out of the head. The genus contains bioluminescent species and has several species groups and subspecies.

edges.c: Histioteuthis uses its larger eye to see ambient sunlight and its smaller eye to detect bioluminescence from prey animals.

edges.c: The name is composed of the Greek histion (ἱστίον, 'sail', a large webbed membrane between six of the arms, in some species) and teuthis ('squid').

nodes: Belman, Bruce W (1978). Respiration and the effects of pressure on the mesopelagic vertically migrating squid Histioteuthis heteropsis. Limnology and Oceanography. 23 (4): 735-9.

edges.c: Histioteuthis heteropsis, also known as the strawberry squid, is a species of small cock-eyed squid. The scientific nomenclature of these squid stems from their set of differently sized eyes, one being small and blue and the other being large and yellow. It is thought that the large eye is used to see objects against dim light, while the smaller eye is more able to view bioluminescent light sources. The squid's vernacular name arose due to its rich red skin pigmentation and the presence of photophores along its body, making it appear like a strawberry with seeds.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Gastropods, commonly known as slugs and snails, belong to a large taxonomic class of invertebrates within the phylum Mollusca called Gastropoda. This class comprises snails and slugs from saltwater, freshwater, and from the land. The class Gastropoda is highly diverse and successful, containing a vast total of named species, second only to the insects in overall number. The anatomy, behavior, feeding, and reproductive adaptations of gastropods vary significantly from one clade or group to another, so stating many generalities for all gastropods is difficult.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The family Homolidae contains 14 genera of marine crabs. They mostly live on the continental slope and continental shelf and are rarely encountered. Members of the Homolidae have their fifth pereiopods (last pair of walking legs) in a sub-dorsal position, which allows them to hold objects in place over the rear half of the carapace. The objects carried include sponges, black corals, and gorgonians, and this behavior may be a defense mechanism against predators. Some species have been observed carrying living sea urchins in a symbiotic relationship which allows them to benefit from the protection of the urchin's dangerous spikes.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The spotted ratfish is a chimaera found in the northeastern Pacific Ocean, known for its distinct appearance, pointed rat-like tail, and large emerald green eyes. It is a cartilaginous fish with a smooth and scaleless silvery-bronze skin, speckled with white spots, and large, triangular pectoral fins. It has a venomous spine and is supported by cartilage rather than bone.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The spotted ratfish can be found in the northeastern Pacific Ocean, ranging from Alaska to Baja California, with an isolated population in the Gulf of California. It is most commonly found off the Pacific Northwest and lives near the sea floor in sandy, muddy, or rocky reef environments. It can be found at depths ranging from 0 to 913 m (0 to 2,995 ft) below sea level.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: It is most common between 50 and 400 m (160 and 1,310 ft) and tends to move closer to shallow water during the spring and autumn, then to deeper water in summer and winter. It prefers temperatures between 7.2 and 8.9 °C (45 and 48 °F), but can move into slightly warmer water seasonally.
edges.label: depth

edges.c: The spotted ratfish feeds on crunchy foods such as crabs and clams, as well as shrimp, worms, small fish, small crustaceans, and sea stars. It swims slowly above the sea floor in search of food and typically hunts at night.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: The spawning season peaks during the spring to autumn, and the female releases up to two fertilized eggs into sand or mud areas of the seabed every 10–14 days. The egg sack is leather-like, 12.7 cm (5.0 in) long, connected to a filament, and development can take up to a year.
edges.label: spawningSeason

edges.c: The ratfish prefers to maintain a safe distance from divers and is usually not aggressive. It can inflict a mildly toxic wound with its dorsal fin spines when it feels threatened. The fish is known for performing barrel rolls and corkscrew turns as it swims, using its large pectoral fins.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: A rare albino Puget Sound ratfish was discovered near Whidbey Island, Washington. It is the only pure albino among the 7.2 million specimens in the University of Washington's fish collection.
edges.label: specialCharacteristic

edges.c: The Eastern Pacific black ghostshark, or Hydrolagus melanophasma, is a species of fish in the family Chimaeridae. Despite its name, it does not belong to the clade Selachii used for the modern classification of sharks. It is, however, distantly related to the sharks in the sense that both are Chondrichthyes (cartilaginous fishes).

edges.c: Ilyophis arx is a marine eel in the family Synaphobranchidae. It was described by Catherine H. Robins in 1976. The eel is known from the eastern Pacific and northeastern Atlantic Ocean, inhabiting deep waters at a depth range of 1,790 to 3,225 meters (5,873 to 10,581 ft). Males of this species can reach a maximum total length of 44.7 centimeters (17.6 in).

It spawns in June and July and primarily feeds on galatheid crustaceans.

edges.c: The Limidae, also known as file shells, are a family of bivalve molluscs in the order Limida. They include 130 living species belonging to 10 genera and are widely distributed in seas worldwide, from shallow to deep waters. These species are known for being epifaunal or nestling, with many building byssal nests for protection. Additionally, many are capable of irregular swimming by waving their long mantle tentacles.

edges.c: Anglerfish are named for their characteristic mode of predation, in which a modified luminescent fin ray (the esca or illicium) acts as a lure for other fish. The luminescence comes from symbiotic bacteria, which are thought to be acquired from seawater. Some anglerfish are notable for extreme sexual dimorphism and sexual symbiosis of the small male with the much larger female.
edges.label: characteristic_predation

edges.c: Anglerfish occur worldwide and can be pelagic (dwelling away from the sea floor) or benthic (dwelling close to the sea floor). Some live in the deep sea, while others live on the continental shelf.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The earliest fossils of anglerfish are from the Eocene Monte Bolca formation of Italy. They likely originated during the Cretaceous and diversified in a short period of the early to mid-Cretaceous, between 130 and 100 million years ago.
edges.label: evolution

edges.c: Anglerfish are carnivorous and have large, crescent-shaped mouths full of long, fang-like teeth angled inward for efficient prey grabbing. They also have a unique flap (illicium) at the distal end of their body on their first dorsal fin, which acts as a luring mechanism where prey approach in a face-to-face manner.
edges.label: carnivorous_adaptation

edges.c: Most adult female ceratioid anglerfish have a luminescent organ called the esca at the tip of a modified dorsal ray, derived from Latin ēsca, meaning 'bait'. The luminescence comes from symbiotic bacteria dwelling in and around the esca.
edges.label: bioluminescence

edges.c: Anglerfish exhibit lethargic behavior suited to the energy-poor environment of the deep sea. They also show burst swimming when approached by predators.
edges.label: swimming_and_energy_conservation

edges.c: Anglerfish use their bioluminescent esca to attract prey, and are opportunistic foragers with a range of preferred prey. They can also emit light from their esca to attract prey.
edges.label: predation

edges.c: Some anglerfish employ an unusual mating method involving sexual symbiosis and extreme sexual dimorphism. Males become dependent on the female host for survival by receiving nutrients via their shared circulatory system, and provide sperm to the female in return.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Northwest European Lophius species are heavily fished, and anglerfish are known to occasionally rise to the surface during El Niño, leaving large groups of dead anglerfish floating on the surface. They are also listed by Greenpeace International as being sourced from unsustainable fisheries.
edges.label: threats

edges.c: Monkfish or goosefish is a commercially important anglerfish in western Europe, eastern North America, Africa, and East Asia. Anglerfish is heavily consumed in South Korea, where it is featured in dishes such as Agujjim.
edges.label: human_consumption

edges.c: Lophiodes beroe is a deep water dwelling fish known for its elusiveness and lack of remarkable traits. It reaches a maximum length of 40 cm and has 19 vertebrae with 6 anal spines and rays. One of its identifying markers is the white humoral spots, visible only on live specimens.

edges.c: Lophiodes beroe can be found on dead coral rubble, Lophelia pertusa, deep in the ocean. It is often found resting and not swimming, functioning as a lie-in-wait predator.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Lophiodes beroe can be found in most of the Atlantic Ocean, ranging from North Carolina to the northern coast of South America, as well as in the Northeastern Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea. It inhabits depths ranging from 370 to 860 meters at temperatures of 9 to 11 degrees Celsius.

edges.c: The Pacific barreleye fish is a genus of ray-finned fish belonging to Opisthoproctidae, containing one species, M. microstoma. It is recognized for its highly unusual transparent, fluid-filled shield on its head, through which the lenses of its eyes can be seen. The eyes can rotate both up and forward in its transparent shield.

edges.c: Macrouridae is a family of deep sea fish within the order Gadiformes. They are characterized by their large heads, slender bodies, and whip-like tails. They have two dorsal fins, a long anal fin, and small scales covering their bodies. Some species exhibit bioluminescence due to symbiotic bioluminescent bacteria. They are mainly benthopelagic and are found at depths of 200–2000 m, with a wide distribution from the Arctic to the Antarctic. They are weak swimmers and some species are of commercial importance to fisheries.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The species in the Macrouridae normally live near the sea bed on the continental slope. Some species are bathypelagic or mesopelagic, and others occur on the outer continental shelf.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Grenadiers, also known as rattails, are large marine fish found at great depths from the Arctic to Antarctic. They are part of the subfamily Macrourinae within the family Macrouridae and are characterized by their slender bodies and rat-like tails.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Majidae is a family of crabs comprising around 200 marine species inside 52 genera. The family is characterized by a carapace that is longer than it is broad and forms a point at the front. edges.c: Meadia abyssalis is a marine, deep water-dwelling eel known from the Indo-Pacific, including Brazil, the Hancock Seamount, the Hawaiian and Society islands, Japan, Mauritius, and Réunion. It was described by Toshiji Kamohara in 1938 and is found off the continental slope at depths ranging from 100 to 329 metres. Males can reach a maximum total length of 73 centimetres.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Mediaster is a genus of starfish in the family Goniasteridae. It was circumscribed in 1857 by William Stimpson for M. aequalis, the genus's type species. Its junior synonym is the genus Isaster, which was circumscribed in 1894 by Addison Emery Verrill for the species now known as M. bairdi. Verrill himself synonymized the two genus names in 1899.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Jellyfish are medusa-phase members of the subphylum Medusozoa, which is a major part of the phylum Cnidaria. They are mainly free-swimming marine animals with umbrella-shaped bells and trailing tentacles.
edges.label: Definition

edges.c: The main feature of a true jellyfish is the umbrella-shaped bell, which consists of a mass of transparent jelly-like matter known as mesoglea.
edges.label: Description

edges.c: Jellyfish move through the water by radially expanding and contracting their bell-shaped bodies to push water behind them and create vortex rings for propulsion. They are considered the most energy-efficient swimmers of all animals.
edges.label: Locomotion

edges.c: Jellyfish have a complex life cycle that includes sexual and asexual phases. They typically spawn, producing larvae that develop into polyps, which then reproduce asexually by budding and form ephyrae that detach and grow into adult medusae.
edges.label: Description

edges.c: Jellyfish range in size from about one millimeter to nearly 2 meters in bell height and diameter. The smallest jellyfish are the creeping jellyfish with bell disks from 0.5 millimeters to a few millimeters, while the lion's mane jellyfish is known as one of the largest.
edges.label: Description

edges.c: Jellyfish are generally carnivorous, feeding on a variety of organisms including planktonic organisms, small fish, fish eggs, other jellyfish, and more. Some species have a symbiotic relationship with microalgae or host parasitic organisms.
edges.label: Diet

edges.c: Jellyfish are predated upon by a variety of marine animals including sea anemones, tunas, sharks, sea turtles, and penguins. However, they are also considered top predators in the food chain.
edges.label: Predation

edges.c: Jellyfish are equipped with stinging cells and their stings can range from mild discomfort to extreme pain and even death. Contact with a jellyfish tentacle can trigger nematocysts to pierce the skin and inject venom. Vinegar and hydrocortisone cream are often used to alleviate the effects of stings.
edges.label: Stings

edges.c: In some cultures, jellyfish are harvested for food and other purposes. They are used in traditional dishes, and their collagen has potential biotechnological applications.
edges.label: Products

edges.c: Jellyfish are harvested in fisheries for export, and they have been studied for their applications in biotechnology, specifically the discovery of green fluorescent protein (GFP).
edges.label: Fishing and Biotechnology

edges.c: Jellyfish can form large masses or blooms under certain environmental conditions, often leading to ecological impacts such as competition with fish for food, impacting fish stocks, and causing harmful effects in industries and tourism.
edges.label: Blooms

edges.c: Jellyfish are displayed in public aquariums, and there is an emerging interest in keeping them in home aquariums.
edges.label: Aquarium Display

edges.c: Jellyfish have been studied for their biotechnological applications, particularly in the discovery and use of green fluorescent protein (GFP) as a genetic marker.
edges.label: Biotechnology

edges.c: A material that, when freshly prepared, polished, or fractured, shows a lustrous appearance, and conducts electricity and heat relatively well. Metals are typically ductile and malleable, and these properties are the result of the metallic bond between the atoms or molecules of the metal.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Metals are shiny and lustrous, with varying densities. They are typically malleable and ductile, deforming under stress without cleaving. The atoms of metallic substances are typically arranged in one of three common crystal structures: body-centered cubic (bcc), face-centered cubic (fcc), and hexagonal close-packed (hcp).
edges.label: form_and_structure

edges.c: Metals are relatively good conductors of electricity and heat. The electronic structure of metals means they have fixed energy levels and correspond to the energy levels at which electrical conduction can occur. The contribution of a metal's electrons to its heat capacity and thermal conductivity, and the electrical conductivity of the metal itself can be calculated from the free electron model.
edges.label: electrical_and_thermal

edges.c: Metals are usually inclined to form cations through electron loss. Most will react with oxygen in the air to form oxides over various timescales. Painting, anodizing, or plating metals are good ways to prevent their corrosion.
edges.label: chemical

edges.c: Metals are found in yellow on the periodic table, while light blue represents giant covalent structures, dark blue molecular covalent structures, and violet single atoms. There is some doubt for uninvestigated elements such as oganesson (Og).
edges.label: periodic_table_distribution

edges.c: Metals make up approximately 25% of the Earth's crust by weight, with nonmetals making up the rest. They are primarily found as lithophiles, or chalcophiles. Gold is a siderophile and is relatively rare.
edges.label: abundance_and_occurrence

edges.c: Metals are often extracted from the Earth by means of mining ores. Once the ore is mined, the metals must be extracted, usually by chemical or electrolytic reduction.
edges.label: extraction

edges.c: An alloy is a substance having metallic properties and which is composed of two or more elements, at least one of which is a metal. Most pure metals are either too soft, brittle, or chemically reactive for practical use, so combining different ratios of metals as alloys modifies the properties of pure metals to produce desirable characteristics.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Ferrous metals contain iron, while non-ferrous metals and alloys lack appreciable amounts of iron.
edges.label: ferrous_and_non-ferrous_metals

edges.c: While nearly all metals are malleable or ductile, a few are brittle.
edges.label: brittle_metals

edges.c: Refractory metals are extraordinarily resistant to heat and wear, such as niobium, molybdenum, tantalum, tungsten, and rhenium.
edges.label: refractory_metals

edges.c: White metals have relatively low melting points, and they include zinc, cadmium, tin, antimony, lead, and bismuth.
edges.label: white_metals

edges.c: Heavy metals are relatively dense, while light metals have lower densities.
edges.label: heavy_and_light_metals

edges.c: Munidopsis is a genus of squat lobster known for its large number of species and its presence in chemosynthetic environments in the ocean. Fossil species have also been found, dating back to the Eocene and Upper Cretaceous of Antarctica.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Mainly found on continental slopes and on abyssal plains, often in chemosynthetic environments in the ocean

edges.c: Fossil species of Munidopsis are known, including specimens from the Campanian (Cretaceous)

edges.c: During surveys of the wreck of the Endurance in 2022, a squat lobster believed to be an unidentified species in the Munidopsis genus was observed
edges.label: notable_occurrence

edges.c: Descriptions of a new genus and forty-six new species of crustaceans of the family Galatheidae, with a list of the known marine species

edges.c: Munnopsidae is a family of asellote isopoda known for being one of the most speciose and frequently collected isopod families. It consists of nine subfamilies, 42 genera, and about 320 species. The family is commonly abundant and diverse in benthic deep-sea communities and has a wide distribution in cold waters.
edges.label: Description

edges.c: Munnopsidae is a family of asellote isopoda known for being one of the most speciose and frequently collected of the known isopod families. It consists of nine subfamilies, 42 genera, and about 320 species. The Munnopsidae is frequently the most abundant and diverse isopod family in benthic deep−sea communities and has a wide distribution in cold waters.
edges.label: Description

edges.c: Frequently the most abundant and diverse isopod family in benthic deep−sea communities
edges.label: Abundance

edges.c: Muraena argus is a species of moray eel found in coral reefs from Mexico to Peru and around the Galápagos Islands. It was described by Franz Steindachner in 1870, originally under the genus Gymnothorax. It dwells at a depth range of 18 to 60 metres (59 to 197 ft). Males can reach a maximum total length of 120 centimetres (47 in), but more commonly reach a TL of 60 centimetres (24 in).
edges.label: description

edges.c: Coral reefs from Mexico to Peru and around the Galápagos Islands
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Due to its wide distribution, lack of known threats, and lack of observed population decline, the IUCN redlist currently lists M. argus as Least Concern
edges.label: threatStatusReason

edges.c: Lanternfish are small mesopelagic fish of the large family Myctophidae. They are represented by 246 species in 33 genera and are found in oceans worldwide. They are named after their conspicuous use of bioluminescence and are among the most widely distributed, diverse, and populous vertebrates.
edges.label: description

edges.label: body

edges.label: head

edges.c: Large terminal mouth with closely set rows of small teeth
edges.label: mouth

edges.c: Small fins including a single high dorsal fin, a forked caudal fin, and an adipose fin
edges.label: fins

edges.c: Presence of light-producing organs (photophores) concentrated in ventrolateral rows on the body and head, emit a weak blue, green, or yellow light

edges.c: Shallow-living species are iridescent blue to green or silver, while deeper-living species are dark brown to black
edges.label: color

edges.c: Known for diel vertical migrations, rising into the epipelagic zone towards sundown and descending back into the lightless depths by daybreak

edges.c: Feed on zooplankton, play a key role in the carbon capture process and are an important link in the food chain of marine ecosystems

edges.c: Lanternfish currently represent one of the dominant groups of mesopelagic fishes in terms of abundance, biomass, and diversity
edges.label: riseToDominance

edges.c: Myroconger gracilis is a marine, deep-water dwelling eel known from the Kyushu–Palau Ridge in the northwestern Pacific Ocean. It dwells at a depth range of 320–640 m. Females are known to reach a maximum standard length of 47.7 cm.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The species epithet gracilis refers to the slender body of the eel in comparison to Myroconger compressus (red eel).
edges.label: epithetMeaning

edges.c: Myroconger seychellensis is a marine, deep-water dwelling eel known from Seychelles in the Indian Ocean. Females can reach a maximum total length of 45 cm. It is known to dwell at a maximum depth of 200 m.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Mysida is an order of small, shrimp-like crustaceans in the malacostracan superorder Peracarida. They are characterized by the presence of a brood pouch in females where the larvae are reared. Their head bears a pair of stalked eyes and two pairs of antennae. The thorax consists of eight segments with branching limbs, all concealed beneath a protective carapace, and the abdomen has six segments with small limbs.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Mysids are found throughout the world in both shallow and deep marine waters, as well as in some freshwater and brackish ecosystems. They can be benthic or pelagic, and some benthic species make daily vertical migrations into higher parts of the water column.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Mysids are filter feeders and omnivores, feeding on algae, detritus, and zooplankton. They are also used as a food source for other cultured marine organisms and are sensitive to water pollution, making them useful as bioindicators to monitor water quality.
edges.label: feeding_habits

edges.c: Mysids have a cosmopolitan distribution and are found in both marine and freshwater environments, including estuaries, shallow coastal waters, lakes, rivers, and underground waters.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Some mysids are benthic or pelagic, while most are found close to or burrowing into the mud or sand. They are important in the diet of fish and exhibit varied feeding behaviors, reproductive patterns, and mutualistic relationships with other marine organisms.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Some species of mysids are cultured in laboratories for experimental purposes and used as a food source for other cultured marine organisms. They are also used in bioassays to test for pesticides and other toxic substances due to their sensitivity to water quality.
edges.label: uses

edges.c: approximately 160 genera, containing more than 1000 species
edges.label: order_size

edges.c: The Mysidacea is a group of shrimp-like crustaceans in the superorder Peracarida, comprising the two extant orders Mysida and Lophogastrida and the prehistoric Pygocephalomorpha.
edges.label: definition

edges.c: The taxon Mysidacea is not used in modern taxonomy.
edges.label: current_taxonomy

edges.c: Current data indicate that despite their external similarities, the three orders are not closely related.
edges.label: relatedness

edges.c: Narcomedusae is an order of hydrozoans in the subclass Trachylinae. Members of this order do not normally have a polyp stage. The medusa has a dome-shaped bell with thin sides. The tentacles are attached above the lobed margin of the bell with usually a gastric pouch above each. There are no bulbs on the tentacles and no radial canals. Narcomedusans are mostly inhabitants of the open sea and deep waters. They can be found in the Mediterranean in large numbers.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Narcomedusae use their tentacles to catch large, fast-moving prey. They do this by holding their tentacles perpendicular to the direction they are swimming to cover a larger area. If something is caught they bend the tentacle inwards and coil them at the tips to their mouths.
edges.label: feedingBehavior

edges.c: Narcomedusae release their eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization happens. Once the eggs are fertilized, they develop into a larval stage called planula and live in the seafloor. They are capable of reproducing all year round, with fluctuations depending on environmental conditions and food availability.
edges.label: reproductionProcess

edges.c: Found in large numbers in the Mediterranean
edges.label: habitatSpecifics

edges.c: Narella is a genus of deep-sea soft corals in the family Primnoidae. They are sessile, bottom-dwelling organisms with a branching appearance.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The name Narella is believed to be derived from the Latin nares, meaning nostril, due to the resemblance of the rows of polyps to small noses.
edges.label: nameOrigin

edges.c: Narella is the most species-rich genus in Primnoidae and has a cosmopolitan distribution. They can be found in all ocean basins, including the Atlantic, the Pacific, the Hawaiian Islands, the Indian Ocean, the Galápagos, and off the coast of Antarctica.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Each region has a distinct group of sympatric species, indicating Narella's high rate of adaptive radiation and potential for many undiscovered species.
edges.label: distinctGroup

edges.c: Over 50 recognized species, with Narella regularis as the type taxon
edges.label: speciesCount

edges.c: Conspicuous polyps with distinct large scales (sclerites). Most species have 16-18 sclerites arranged in pairs. Polyps are covered with opercular scales, each paired together, giving them a symmetrical appearance. Physical differences among species primarily involve the shape and texture of the scales. Corals have aragonite axes and spicules made of high Mg calcite. They anchor themselves using calcareous discoid holdfasts.
edges.label: distinguishingFeatures

edges.c: Branching appearance is the primary identification guide due to difficulty in identifying scale characteristics in the field.
edges.label: fieldIdentification

edges.c: The name Narella is believed to be derived from the latin nares, meaning nostril, due to the resemblance of the rows of polyps to small noses.
edges.label: meaning

edges.c: Narella can be found in all ocean basins and has a cosmopolitan distribution, with species occurring in the Atlantic, the Pacific, the Hawaiian Islands, the Indian Ocean, the Galápagos, and off the coast of Antarctica.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Narella is distinguished from other members of Primnoidae by their conspicuous polyps which have very distinct large scales, also called sclerites. Most species of Narella have 16 - 18 sclerites that are always arranged in pairs. The axis of corals in this genus are made of aragonite, while their spicules are made of high Mg calcite. They anchor themselves to hard substrates using calcareous discoid holdfasts.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The understanding of Narella and its members was established in the late 20th century. The genus was described in 1870 by John Edward Gray, and the first species in the genus was described in 1860. Several new species of Narella were discovered in 1887 but were initially described as members of new genera. It was only in 1951 that these genera were synonymized with Narella by Frederick Bayer.
edges.label: discovery

edges.c: Nemertea is a phylum of animals consisting of about 1300 known species, also known as ribbon worms or proboscis worms. They are characterized by their slim, elongated bodies and possess an eversible proboscis used for capturing prey, a rhynchocoel, a nervous system characterized by a ring of ganglia and ventral nerve cords, and a primitive circulatory system for transport of nutrients and waste products. Most nemerteans are marine, but some are found in freshwater and terrestrial environments.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Nemerteans are mostly soft-bodied, and their fossils are rare. Fossils have been reported from the Triassic and Ordovician periods, and a fossil with nemertean characteristics was found in the Middle Cambrian Burgess Shale. Molecular phylogenetic analyses suggest nemerteans are part of the Lophotrochozoa, sharing relationships with annelids and mollusks.

edges.c: Nephtheidae is a family of soft corals known for their attractive appearance and wide range of colors, including reds, pinks, yellows, and purples. They are popular among reef aquarium hobbyists and are characterized by their arborescent structure with retractable polyps during the day and extending tentacles resembling flowers at night. Also known as broccoli corals due to their appearance.

edges.c: Nidaliidae is a family of soft corals in the phylum Cnidaria. Some members of this family are similar in appearance to gorgonians (sea fans). They are difficult to keep in the reef aquarium because they do not contain symbiotic zooxanthellae and therefore need to be fed on zooplankton. Others, in the genera Agaricoides, Nidalla and Pieterfaurea, more resemble members of the family Nephtheidae and these are somewhat easier to keep in the aquarium.

edges.c: The East Pacific red octopus, or Octopus rubescens, is the most commonly occurring shallow-water octopus on much of the North American West Coast. Its range extends from the southern Gulf of California to at least the Gulf of Alaska, and it may also occur in the western Pacific Ocean. It can be found intertidally to a depth of 300 m (980 ft).
edges.label: description

edges.c: The taxonomy of Octopus rubescens remains somewhat unresolved. It was previously considered to be a young Enteroctopus dofleini. The species may represent several subspecies or a species complex.

edges.c: It pounces on prey and displays a stereotypical sequence of color changes at the moment of capture. It may drill a hole through the shell of bivalve prey to deliver venom and open the shell more easily. Recent studies suggest it may choose prey based on fat digestibility rather than calories.

edges.c: Ophichthidae is a family of fish in the order Anguilliformes, commonly known as the snake eels. They have long, cylindrical, snake-like bodies and are burrowing eels. They are found worldwide in tropical to warm temperate waters and inhabit a wide range of habitats, from coastal shallows to depths below 800 m. Most species are bottom dwellers, hiding in mud or sand to capture their prey of crustaceans and small fish. The family comprises species ranging in total length from 5 cm to 2.3 m or more. Many species lack fins altogether, improving their ability to burrow into the substrate like worms. They are often spotted or striped in color, mimicking the appearance of venomous sea snakes to deter predators.
edges.label: description

Males can reach a maximum total length of 47.3 centimetres.

edges.c: Ophiuridae are a large family of brittle stars of the suborder Ophiurina. The arms are simple and unbranched, projecting from and well-fused to the edge of the disc. The arm spines are short and movable, lying flat against the arms when stimulated, but held erect when the brittle star is at rest. Disc and arms are covered in naked, distinct scales, situated at both sides of the disc. The jaw is surrounded by a continuous series of mouth papillae. The base of the arm contains a single arm comb or an inner and outer arm comb.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The fossils of Ophiuridae date back to Carboniferous (Aganaster†).

edges.c: Ostracods are a class of small crustaceans, typically around 1mm in size, with a diverse range of diets and a wide distribution in marine and freshwater environments. They are encased in a bivalve-like shell made of chitin and usually calcium carbonate and have a unique reproductive system, which includes large coiled sperm in males and brood care in some species.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Ostracods are the most common arthropods in the fossil record, with fossils dating back to the early Ordovician period. They are valuable for biozonation of marine strata and as indicators of paleoenvironments.
edges.label: record

edges.c: Guinness World Record for the oldest penis and largest sperm recorded in an animal
edges.label: significance

edges.c: The body is encased by a bivalve carapace and consists of a head and thorax, with various appendages serving different functions. Ostracods have a pair of 'ventilatory appendages' for creating a water current and exhibit diverse sensory organs and respiratory systems.
edges.label: body

edges.c: The carapace develops from two independent buds of the carapace valves that meet in the middle during growth.
edges.label: carapaceOrigin

edges.c: Most species have lost trunk segmentation, and the head is the largest part of the body, bearing four pairs of appendages.
edges.label: segmentation

edges.c: Inferring palaeotemperatures based on oxygen isotope and calcium-magnesium ratio analysis of ostracod valves
edges.label: use

edges.c: Ostracods can be part of the zooplankton or benthos in marine environments and are found in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial habitats, including extreme environments such as sulfidic caves, deep groundwaters, and hot springs.
edges.label: ecologicalNiche

edges.c: Around 2000 species and 200 genera of non-marine ostracods have been documented, with a large portion of diversity still undescribed.
edges.label: diversity

edges.c: Ostracods exhibit diverse reproductive strategies, including large coiled sperm, swarming, parthenogenesis, and brood care, and have a unique lifecycle with direct development and variable instar counts.
edges.label: lifecycle

edges.c: They are preyed upon by a variety of fauna in aquatic and terrestrial environments, including amphibians and certain clams.
edges.label: predators

edges.c: Some ostracods exhibit bioluminescence, using it for predation defense and in courtship displays, with bioluminescent courtship displays associated with higher speciation rates.
edges.label: bioluminescence
