edges.c: The Paguridae is a family of hermit crabs belonging to the order Decapoda. The king crabs, Lithodoidea, are believed to have evolved from within the Paguridae, with some authors suggesting their ancestors were within the genus Pagurus.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Hermit crabs are decapod crustaceans of the superfamily Paguroidea that have adapted to occupy empty scavenged mollusc shells to protect their fragile exoskeletons.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Hermit crabs are found in almost all marine environments, ranging from shallow reefs and shorelines to deep sea bottoms. Some species are also terrestrial and require access to both freshwater and saltwater to survive.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Mostly marine, living in depths of saltwater. They breathe through gills and can survive briefly out of water if their gills are damp.

edges.c: Terrestrial species found in tropical areas, requiring access to both freshwater and saltwater to keep their gills damp or wet to survive and reproduce.

edges.c: The fossil record of in situ hermit crabs using gastropod shells stretches back to the Late Cretaceous. The earliest record of the superfamily extends back to the earliest part of the Jurassic.

edges.c: Long, spirally curved and soft, unlike the hard, calcified abdomens seen in related crustaceans. The vulnerable abdomen is protected by a salvaged empty seashell.

edges.c: Several species of hermit crabs are kept as pets, with some species having a lifespan of up to 20 years if properly cared for.

edges.c: Barracudinas are elongated, slender fish with large eyes, and a pointed snout containing fang-like teeth. They are found almost worldwide in deep waters and are related to lizardfish. They lack swim bladders and are simultaneous hermaphrodites, a reproductive mode which is rare among vertebrates. Barracudinas have unique adaptations for camouflage in the deep pelagic, including a subdermal layer of guanine and transparent skin among some species. They are known to inhabit mesopelagic depths throughout the world's oceans, and are predators of fish, shrimps, and squids. While they are rarely caught by fisheries, they are frequently documented in the guts of pelagic predators such as tuna, swordfish, lancetfish, Cuvier's beaked whales, and blue sharks.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Paranthias colonus, also known as the Pacific creolefish, is a species of grouper found in the Eastern Pacific Ocean. They are known to form small aggregations above reefs and retreat to the reef when in danger. They feed on plankton and can be found at depths of up to 100m. The body is elongate and fusiform with a small head and convex profiles. They have specific fin and ray counts and can grow up to approximately 36 cm. The coloration varies between young and adult individuals, with young ones being bright yellow with dark spots and adults being greenish brown dorsally and reddish below, with five white or blue-white spots on the back. The fins are reddish.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The Pacific creolefish is found in the Eastern Pacific from the Gulf of California to Peru, including the Revillagigedo, Galapagos, Clipperton, Cocos Island, and Malpelo islands.

edges.c: Paraulopus is the only genus in the family Paraulopidae, a family of grinners in the order Aulopiformes. They are commonly known as cucumberfishes, but locally some other Teleostei are also known by that name. They were considered in the Chlorophthalmidae or greeneye family until 2001. The fishes tend to be slender and cylindrical, with large eyes and a large terminal mouth with only slightly protruding lower jaw. The earliest known fossil evidence of cucumberfishes are otoliths from the Aptian and Albian of Spain, France, and Texas. It remains uncertain whether these otoliths actually belong to Paraulopus itself or to an extinct fossil paraulopid genus.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phaeodarea, also known as Phaeodaria, is a group of amoeboid cercozoan organisms that are traditionally considered radiolarians but molecular trees have placed them among the Cercozoa. They are distinguished by the structure of their central capsule and the presence of a phaeodium, an aggregate of waste particles within the cell.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phaeodarea are unicellular protists that grow a capsule with a thick, double-layered wall containing astropylum or oral pores and parapylae or lateral pores. They have a large, often darkly pigmented mass of granular cytoplasm called phaeodium external to the capsule. Their mitochondrial cristae are tubular.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phaeodarea are heterotrophic plankton (zooplankton) that chiefly live in pelagic open oceans. They have a continuous strand of cytoplasm in the astropyle that carries digested prey matter into the endoplasm. Limited evidence suggests they feed on microflagellates, metazoans, copepods, and salps.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sexual reproduction of Phaeodaria has not been confirmed, but the release of motile swarmers that are likely gametes is widely documented. Some species disperse by producing multinucleated amoebae that eventually form swarmers with two undulipodia (flagella).
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phaeodarea are exclusively marine, holoplanktonic unicellular protists that play an important role in marine ecosystems, living in pelagic open oceans from the surface to the deep sea. They are heterotrophic plankton and are present in all oceans.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phaeodaria were historically regarded as Radiolaria, along with Polycystinea and Acantharea, due to their elaborate siliceous skeletons and central capsule with pores from which axopodia emerge. Through molecular phylogenetics, Phaeodaria are now classified as a subclass of the phylum Cercozoa, within the higher Rhizaria supergroup.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phaeodarea is a monophyletic clade consisting of 11 subclades. The current taxonomy by Cavalier-Smith divides Phaeodarea into two orders: Eodarida and Opaloconchida, each containing suborders, families, and genera.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The modern classification of Phaeodarea consists of the subclass containing 2 orders (Eodarida and Opaloconchida), 7 suborders, 16 families, and 39 genera, as proposed by Cavalier-Smith in 2012.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phoronids are marine animals that filter-feed with a lophophore and build upright tubes of chitin to support and protect their soft bodies. They are found in most oceans and seas, excluding the Antarctic Ocean.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phoronids inhabit the intertidal zone and can be found at depths of up to 400 meters. They live in vertical tubes embedded in soft sediment or form tangled masses buried in rocks and shells.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Most adult phoronids are 2 cm long and about 1.5 mm wide, although the largest can grow up to 50 cm long.
edges.label: size

edges.c: A flask-like swelling at the bottom end of the body that anchors the animal in the tube and enables it to retract its body when threatened.
edges.label: ampulla

edges.c: A crown of tentacles at the top of the body, which is used for filter-feeding and respiration.
edges.label: lophophore

edges.c: Phoronids secrete rigid tubes of chitin to protect their soft bodies. These tubes can be reinforced with sediment particles and other debris.
edges.label: tubes

edges.c: Phoronids filter-feed using their lophophores, with cilia on the sides of the tentacles drawing in water and food particles.
edges.label: feeding

edges.c: They rely on respiration through the lophophore and do not ventilate their trunks with oxygenated water. The blood contains hemoglobin to adapt to anoxic and hypoxic environments.
edges.label: respiration

edges.c: Solid wastes are moved up the intestine and out through the anus.
edges.label: excretion

edges.c: Phoronids reproduce sexually from spring to autumn. Some species are hermaphroditic and cross-fertilize, while others have separate sexes.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Most species form free-swimming actinotroch larvae, which feed on plankton and undergo metamorphosis to become adult phoronids.
edges.label: larvae

edges.c: In some habitats, populations of phoronids can reach tens of thousands of individuals per square meter.
edges.label: populationDensity

edges.c: Predators of phoronids include fish, gastropods, and nematodes. Some species have effective defenses against predators.
edges.label: predators

edges.c: There are no indisputable body fossils of phoronids, but there is evidence of trace fossils attributed to Phoronis in various periods from the Silurian to the Cretaceous.
edges.label: fossilRecord

edges.c: Phoronids, brachiopods, and bryozoans are collectively called lophophorates, although their exact relationship and evolutionary history is still subject to debate.
edges.label: familyTree

edges.c: Phronima is a genus of small, deep sea hyperiid amphipods of the family Phronimidae. It is found throughout the world's oceans, except in polar regions. Phronima species live in the pelagic zone of the deep ocean. Their bodies are semitransparent.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Phronima species live in the pelagic zone of the deep ocean, found throughout the world's oceans, except in polar regions.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Instead of constantly feeding on a live host, females attack salps, using their mouths and claws to eat the animal and hollow out its gelatinous shell. Phronima females then enter the barrel and lay their eggs inside, then propel the barrel through the water as the larvae develop, providing them with fresh food and water.
edges.label: feeding behavior

edges.c: Phronima sedentaria is a species of amphipod crustaceans known for their large size relative to other members of the family Phronimidae. Males are around 15 mm long, while females can measure up to 42 mm in length. They possess a complex optical system with two sets of compound eyes and exhibit sexual dimorphism.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Found in oceans at a depth of up to 1 km (0.6 mi), typically in temperate, subtropical, and tropical waters of all the world's oceans, including the Mediterranean Sea. The species is usually found in midwater pelagic habitats but can be found migrating all the way to the surface.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Exhibits a symbiotic relationship with tunicates of the genera Pyrosoma spp., Doliolum spp., and Salpa spp., displaying behaviors that suggest commensalism, parasitism, and predation. They are also known to be carnivorous on zooplankton, krill, arrowworms, and other crustaceans.
edges.label: symbioticRelationship

edges.c: Uses different feeding techniques depending on the food source, primarily using the leading sets of pereiopods (front legs) for feeding. Feeding preferentially occurs at nighttime when the species undergoes a vertical migration to the ocean's surface.
edges.label: feedingStrategies

edges.c: Females can produce up to 600 eggs at a time and juveniles spend their early development within the mother in a specialized pouch called the marsupium. Offspring are fed and cared for by the mother until they reach prematurity and are able to feed and survive independently.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Phymorhynchus is a genus of sea snails in the family Raphitomidae. The fusiform shell is thin, smooth, or spirally sculptured. The axial sculpture is less conspicuous. The siphonal canal is nearly obsolete. The columella and outer lip are simple. The anal sulcus is wide, shallow, and close to the suture. The animal is blind, with a distinct muzzle into which the proboscis is retracted. The operculum is wanting.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Physiculus rastrelliger is a species of bathydemersal fish found in the eastern Pacific Ocean. It reaches a length of 25.0 cm (9.8 in).
edges.label: description

edges.c: Madagascar to the Marianas, including the Kyushu-Palau Ridge and the northern Hawaiian Ridge
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Physonectae is a suborder of siphonophores, composed of pelagic organisms forming colonies of specialized zooids originating from the same fertilized egg.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The majority of physonect siphonophores are pelagic, with the exception of Rhodallidae, which are a family of benthic physonects. Physonects are known to be widely distributed globally, although their exact global distributions are unclear due to being understudied and often misidentified.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: All physonect siphonophores have an aboral, apical pneumatophore filled with gas, formed by invagination of the superficial cell layers of the larva. The pneumatophore plays a role in controlling gas volume and pressure for buoyancy control.
edges.label: pneumatophore

edges.c: The nectosome is composed of asexual nectophores, or swimming bells, specialized for swimming.
edges.label: nectosome

edges.c: The siphophore includes the gastrozooids (feeding polyps) and sexual medusoids.
edges.label: siphosome

edges.c: Each physonect colony is composed of individual organisms originating from the same fertilized egg, with specialized functions including locomotion, feeding, and reproduction. The ventral budding zone of the nectophores produces new buds asexually.
edges.label: budding

edges.c: Sexual reproduction occurs to give rise to a new colony of zooids. Many physonect siphonophores are monoecious, some are protandrous, and few are dioecious. Fertilization happens externally.
edges.label: sexualReproduction

edges.c: The life cycle of physonects involves external fertilization, formation of planula, development into siphonula, and maturation into a young colony, eventually becoming a mature colony. Most physonectae are pelagic throughout their entire life cycles.
edges.label: lifeStages

edges.c: Physonectae are carnivorous predators and primarily consume large copepods, smaller copepods, arthropods, chaetognaths, fish larvae, and other large, non-copepod prey.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Planctoteuthis is a genus of chiroteuthid squid comprising five species, occurring worldwide in lower mesopelagic to bathypelagic depths in tropical to temperate waters. It has been suggested that members of Planctoteuthis are neotenic, retaining characteristics of the doratopsis developmental stage. This is marked in the retention of the paralarval tentacular club, unique among subadult chiroteuthids. Members lack both photophores and a funnel valve.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Fin length greater than half of the mantle
edges.label: distinguishingFeatures

edges.c: From 700 m (2,300 ft) to in excess of 1,000 m (3,300 ft)
edges.label: habitatForLargerSpecimens

edges.c: Eastern Pacific Ocean, North Atlantic Ocean
edges.label: additionalRecordedLocations

edges.c: Platyhelminthes are a phylum of relatively simple bilaterian, unsegmented, soft-bodied invertebrates. Unlike other bilaterians, they are acoelomates and have no specialized circulatory and respiratory organs. They are divided into free-living flatworms and parasitic groups like Cestoda, Trematoda, and Monogenea.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Their left and right sides are mirror images of each other, with distinct top and bottom surfaces.
edges.label: description

edges.c: They have no body cavity, unlike most other bilaterians.
edges.label: description

edges.c: They lack specialized circulatory and respiratory organs and have soft, unsegmented bodies.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Mostly free-living, ranging from 1 mm to 600 mm in length, and mainly predators or scavengers. Some are symbiotes or parasites. Many have pigment-cup ocelli and some are hermaphrodites.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Parasitic flatworms known as flukes, with often complex life cycles and different stages infesting multiple hosts. Includes Digenea and Aspidogastrea groups.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Parasitic flatworms with Monogenea and Cestoda groupings. Monogeneans are mainly external parasites, while Cestodes are internal parasites known as tapeworms.
edges.label: description

edges.c: part of Lophotrochozoa, closely related to Gastrotricha
edges.label: Platyzoa

edges.c: Can cause diseases in humans and livestock, with some species causing tropical diseases like schistosomiasis. Infection with tapeworms and flukes can lead to serious health problems.
edges.label: impact

edges.c: Rising threat in developed countries due to social trends, and spreads in less-developed countries due to poor sanitation and water supply.
edges.label: spread

edges.c: Some planarian species have been used to control pests like the giant African snail, and have shown potential to reduce populations of mosquito species.
edges.label: control

edges.c: Some flatworm species pose a threat to native snails and earthworms and are of concern in certain regions.
edges.label: conservationConcerns

edges.c: Cestode eggs found in a Permian shark coprolite, with possible older fossils from the Devonian and Early Cambrian
edges.label: oldestIdentified

edges.c: Indo-Pacific, widely distributed in various locations including KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, Mozambique, the Gulf of Mannar, the northern Andaman Islands, the South China Sea, the Ryukyu Islands, the Kyushu-Palau Ridge, Australia, New Caledonia, and Hawaii.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Inhabits the upper continental slope at depths of 275–680 m (900–2,230 ft), over muddy or silty substrates.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Oval pectoral fin disc, long, flexible, broad-angled snout, distinctively long, slender, leaf-shaped caudal fin. Purplish brown to blackish above with white underside and dark tail and caudal fin.
edges.label: physicalAppearance

edges.c: Preys on crustaceans, cephalopods, and bony fishes, hunting on the sea floor and in open water.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Moved to its own genus, Plesiobatis, and family, Plesiobatidae, based on morphological studies.

edges.c: Capable of inflicting serious injuries with its long, venomous sting when captured.
edges.label: injuries

edges.c: Captured incidentally by deepwater bottom trawls and longlines, minimal threat from current small-scale fisheries.
edges.label: fishingImpact

edges.c: Pleurobranchaea is a genus of sea slugs, specifically sidegill slugs or notaspideans. These are marine gastropod molluscs in the family Pleurobranchaeidae. The genus is differentiated from other sidegill slugs by its rhinophores, which are well separated, rather than being joined under the notum.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Depend on signal cues sensed from their chemical receptors for localized feeding
edges.label: feeding_behavior

edges.c: Aposematic learning to avoid animals with noxious defenses
edges.label: defense_mechanism

edges.c: internal, reduced or lost completely in adults

edges.c: chemical secretions from glandular mantle, including sulfuric acid production
edges.label: defense_mechanism

edges.c: Grimothea planipes is a bright red animal, up to 13 centimetres (5.1 in) long. It resembles a true lobster, but has a shorter abdomen.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Grimothea planipes lives on the continental shelf west of Mexico. It is usually found only south-west of San Diego, but in warmer years, its range may extend northwards into California. The southern limit of the species' range is in Chile.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The life cycle of Grimothea planipes includes planktonic larvae being swept by the California Current thousands of miles out to sea. A solution was proposed whereby the larvae use an opposing undercurrent at a lower depth to return to the continental shelf.
edges.label: life cycle

edges.c: Grimothea planipes usually feeds on protists and zooplankton, but will feed by filtering blooms of diatoms. It is an important food item for many species of birds, marine mammals, and fish. It is favored by tuna and is also known to be consumed by billfishes, yellowtail amberjack, sharks, Epinephelus analogus, gray whales, Bryde's whales, blue whales, sea otters, the Mexican endemic bat Myotis vivesi, loggerhead sea turtles, and seabirds like the herring gull (Larus argentuatus). Large numbers of Grimothea planipes washed ashore can be a valuable addition to the diets of seabirds, especially in El Niño years.
edges.label: ecology

edges.c: Pleuronectidae, also known as righteye flounders, are a family of flounders characterized by their positioning on the sea bottom on their left sides with both eyes on their right sides.

edges.c: Pleurotomariidae is a family of large marine gastropods with a very ancient lineage, having numerous species in the geological past. The living species are found only in deep water and have a trochoidal-shaped shell with a nacreous interior and a deep slit in the outer superior margin of the peristome. The animal has no frontal lobes or appendages, and the eyes are situated at the outer bases of the tentacles.

edges.c: The Pneumodermatidae are a family of sea angels, which are small floating predatory sea snails or sea slugs. They are pelagic marine heterobranch opisthobranch gastropod mollusks in the clade Gymnosomata.
edges.label: description

edges.c: These small pelagic snails lack shells, except in their early embryonic stage.
edges.label: Shells

edges.c: They are carnivores, equipped with swimming parapoda (fleshy, wing-like outgrowths), strong jaws, and grasping tentacles, often with suckers resembling those of cephalopods.

edges.c: The Poecilopsettidae are a family of flatfish in the order Pleuronectiformes. They comprise three genera and 21 species and are typically demersal, living on marine bottoms at depths between 60 and 500 m (200 and 1,640 ft) in the Indo-Pacific and northwestern Atlantic. The deepest recorded occurrence is 1,636 m (5,367 ft) in the deepwater dab, Poecilopsetta beanii. Sizes range from 9 to 19 cm (3.5 to 7.5 in) in length, though most species are usually under 15 cm (5.9 in) long. Their diets consist of zoobenthos.

edges.c: Poecilosclerida is an order of the demosponge class known for its diversity, with over 2200 species. The order is characterized by the presence of chelae microscleres and viviparous nature with uniformly ciliated parenchymella larvae.

edges.c: Poeobius is a genus of marine polychaete worm, containing the single species Poeobius meseres, also known as balloon worm. It is a common and abundant resident in the midwater around the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones, especially in Monterey Bay.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Poeobius meseres can be found at depths of around 300-2,500 m (980-8,200 ft) from Japan to Alaska to the Gulf of California, and have also been reported in South America.

edges.c: Polychaeta is a paraphyletic class of generally marine annelid worms, commonly called bristle worms or polychaetes.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Less than 10 cm in length, although ranging from 1 mm to 3 m
edges.label: size

edges.c: Each segment has a pair of fleshy protrusions called parapodia that bear many bristles, called chaetae, which are made of chitin. The head includes two to four pairs of eyes, antennae, tentacle-like palps, and pits lined with cilia known as nuchal organs.
edges.label: body features

edges.c: Primarily through the parapodia, some species may have external gills
edges.label: respiration

edges.c: Usually presents a simple but well-developed circulatory system with main blood vessels and smaller vessels supplying the parapodia and gut
edges.label: circulatory system

edges.c: Consists of a ventral nerve cord, ganglia, and sensory organs on the head
edges.label: nervous system

edges.c: Most have separate sexes, shed immature gametes into the body cavity, and fertilize their eggs externally. Some reproduce by epitoky, where the worm undergoes a remarkable transformation as new, specialized segments grow from its rear end until it can be clearly divided into two halves.
edges.label: reproductive strategies

edges.c: Polychaetes are found in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial environments. Their lifestyle varies widely, including burrowing, swimming, pelagic life, tube-dwelling, boring, commensalism, and parasitism.
edges.label: ecological niche

edges.c: Predominantly marine, but many species also live in freshwater, and a few in terrestrial environments. Some species swim among the plankton or above the abyssal plain, while most burrow or build tubes in the sediment and some live as commensals. A few species are parasitic.
edges.label: habitats

edges.c: Polynoidae is a family of marine Polychaete worms known as "scale worms" due to the scale-like elytra on the dorsal surface. They are active hunters, but generally dwell in protected environments such as under stones. The group is widely distributed from shallow intertidal waters to hadal trenches.

There are 15-20 unbranched fin rays in the pectoral fin. They have ctenoid scales on the body, with the cheek, postorbital area, and top of the head scaled. They do not have an occipital pit.

edges.c: Psolidae is a family of small and inconspicuous sea cucumbers found in crevices and under boulders. They have elongated bodies, leathery skins, and a crown of branched tentacles. Members of Psolidae have calcareous plates on the skin of the trunk and a basal sole that can move across the substrate. Some genera have papillae above but these are lacking in species of the genus Psolus.

edges.c: Psychropotes is a genus of sea cucumbers known for their ability to swim, although this is only facultative. Adults are roughly cylindrical in shape and red to violet in color. They possess a sail-like appendage that is used for swimming during the larval stage but is no longer needed when fully grown. Larvae are benthopelagic and transparent, growing to around 2 cm long.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Psychropotidae is a family of deep-sea swimming sea cucumbers characterized by their elongate shape, depressed anterior dorsal surface, large posterior appendage, 10-20 tentacles and ventrolateral radii with small tube feet. They have calcareous deposits and a low degree of calcification, mainly consisting of connective tissue. The calcareous ring is incomplete with 5 independent parts, and they have unique sclerites in papillae. Some species may also exhibit swimming behavior and use dorsal appendages for movement.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Psychropotidae can swim short distances, with certain species spending much of their juvenile phase in the pelagic zone. Some species can use a large dorsal appendage as a 'sail' to move with the prevailing current. The ventral coloration may serve as camouflage from predators above and below.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Traditionally, Psychropotidae have been placed in the same taxon as the family Deimatidae, but recent molecular phylogenetic data suggests that the taxon is polyphyletic, with Deimatidae separated from all other Elasipoda families.
edges.label: taxonomy

edges.c: The ovary in psychropotid species is a large thick-walled nodular structure containing oocytes, with an interspecific maximum size of 1.2 mm to 3 mm. The testes are well-developed structures packed with spermatozoa, except in specimens infested with protozoan parasites. Some species have notably large eggs, with Psychropotes longicauda having the largest known egg size in holothurians at 4.4 mm.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Pterasteridae is a family of sea stars primarily found in deep waters. They have an inflated aboral surface and a hole in the middle of the central disc called "osculum" for expelling mucus to defend against predators. Some species brood their young in internal chambers flushed with seawater. Fossil pterasterids have been found as early as the upper Campanian of the Cretaceous period.

edges.c: The sunflower sea star, Pycnopodia helianthoides, is a large sea star found in the northeastern Pacific Ocean. It is the only species of its genus and is among the largest sea stars in the world, with a maximum arm span of 1 m (3.3 ft). Adult sunflower sea stars usually have 16 to 24 limbs and vary in color. They are carnivorous animals, feeding mostly on sea urchins, clams, sea snails, and other small invertebrates. The species is classified as Critically Endangered on the IUCN Red List.

edges.c: Pyrosoma atlanticum is a cylindrical, pelagic marine colonial tunicate that can grow up to 60 cm long and 4–6 cm wide. It is bioluminescent, emitting a brilliant blue-green light when stimulated. The colony is propelled through the water, catching plankton and other food particles in mucus filters.

edges.c: Found in temperate waters worldwide, usually between 50°N and 50°S, at depths below 250 m. Colonies undergo diurnal migration, rising toward the surface in the evening and descending around dawn.

edges.c: Efficient grazers of particles above 10 µm in diameter, utilizing high biomass intake as a strategy. Growth occurs by budding off new rings of zooids. Each zooid has luminescent organs that produce rhythmic flashing when stimulated.

edges.c: The microbiome of Pyrosoma atlanticum may contribute to its bioluminescence, with the abundance of Photobacterium being a possible source. A potential endogenous pyrosome luciferase has also been identified in its transcriptome.

edges.c: Houses various organisms including penaeid shrimp, amphipods such as Phronima and Phronimella spp. Predators include bony fishes, dolphins, and whales.

edges.c: The Radiolaria, also called Radiozoa, are protozoa of diameter 0.1–0.2 mm that produce intricate mineral skeletons, typically with a central capsule dividing the cell into the inner and outer portions of endoplasm and ectoplasm. They are found as zooplankton throughout the global ocean and are primarily heterotrophic but many have photosynthetic endosymbionts, making them mixotrophs.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The relationship between the Foraminifera and Radiolaria is debated. Molecular trees support their close relationship—a grouping termed Retaria.

edges.c: Rajiformes is one of the four orders in the superorder Batoidea, consisting of flattened cartilaginous fishes related to sharks. They are distinguished by greatly enlarged pectoral fins, a generally flattened body, and exhibit rajiform locomotion.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Rajoids typically have a dorsoventrally flattened body, a slender and pointed snout, wide mouth, well-developed spiracles, and gill slits located on the ventral surface just behind the head. They also have enlarged pectoral fins, two dorsal fins, and a whip-like tail with no caudal fin.
edges.label: body

edges.c: Most species have thorn-like dermal denticles on their skin, often with a row of large denticles along the spine. The eyes and spiracles are located on the upper surface of the head.
edges.label: skin

edges.c: Most species give birth to live young, although some lay eggs enclosed in a horny capsule known as 'mermaid's purse'.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Species of the order Rajiformes are found throughout the world's oceans, from Arctic to Antarctic waters, and from shallow coastal shelves to open seas and abyssal regions. Some are found in rivers and estuaries, but most are marine and live near the sea bed at depths down to 3,000 m (9,800 ft) or more.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Most species are carnivorous, feeding on molluscs, invertebrates, and small fish. The manta ray, however, feeds on plankton sieved out of the water. Some species swim by undulating their enlarged pectoral fins, while others propel themselves through the water with sideways movements of their tail and caudal fin.
edges.label: feeding

edges.c: Most species are viviparous or ovoviviparous, whereas skates lay eggs enclosed in horny cases known as mermaid's purses. Most species are benthic, resting on the sea bed or pelagic, continually cruising the ocean.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Chimaeras are soft-bodied, shark-like fish with bulky heads and long, tapered tails. They have smooth skin, lack scales or unique features, and their skeletons are cartilaginous. They have a large triangular first dorsal fin and a low rectangular or depressed second dorsal fin. Some species have a venomous spine on the front edge of the dorsal fin. The bulbous snout is modified into an elongated sensory organ capable of electroreception to find prey. Unlike sharks, they have separate anal and urogenital openings and a holostylic cartilaginous skull.

edges.c: Rathbunaster is a monospecific genus of sea stars in the family Asteriidae. The genus name was given by Walter Kenrick Fisher to honor the starfish biologist Richard Rathbun of the Smithsonian Institution. The only species in the genus, Rathbunaster californicus, has a maximum size of about 45 centimeters in diameter and an average weight of 35 g. It lives on muddy benthic substrates between 60 and 1,000 m below the surface, covered in spikes with pincers used for capturing prey for consumption.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Rathbunaster californicus lives along the west coast of North America from southern California to southern Alaska. It is found in muddy substrates in deep ocean/benthic environments at depths of 60 to 1,000 m below the surface.

edges.c: The Rhinochimaeridae, commonly known as long-nosed chimaeras, are a family of cartilaginous fish. The snout has numerous sensory nerve endings, and is used to find food such as small fish. The first dorsal fin includes a mildly venomous spine, used in defense.

edges.c: Rossellidae is a family of glass sponges belonging to the order Lyssacinosa. The family has a cosmopolitan distribution and is found at a large range of depths (8–6,770 m (26–22,211 ft), and likely deeper). The body is usually a cup-like structure. In stalked forms, the body can be mushroom-like. The choanosomal skeleton consists of diactines, sometimes together with less frequent hexactines. A large variety of microscleres occur in this family, including a variety of holactinoidal and asterous spicules.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Oilfish have a cosmopolitan distribution in tropical and temperate oceans and are found at depths from 100 to 800 metres (330 to 2,620 ft), but most often between 200 and 400 metres (660 and 1,310 ft). They are distributed throughout tropical and temperate waters across the world, being recorded in the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific oceans, including the Mediterranean Sea.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Oilfish are large, fusiform fish which often grow to 1.5 metres (4.9 ft) and a maximum of 3 metres (9.8 ft). They have large fangs, rough scales, two pairs of finlets, and a uniformly brown coloration. The meat of Oilfish is extremely oily, containing high lipid concentrations. Although edible, the oil mainly consists of wax esters, which makes the meat act as a laxative if consumed in large quantities.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Oilfish are found in the deep water benthic environments of continental slopes and seamounts, where they group in pairs or remain solitary. If food is scarce on the seafloor, at night Oilfish will rise to the surface to prey on other fish, cephalopods, and crustaceans.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Fisheries targeting Oilfish are rare, occurring in small regions of the Atlantic and Pacific through the use of handlines. However, Oilfish are common bycatch for fisheries targeting Tuna and Swordfish, which employ longlines. Despite their laxative-inducing flesh, Oilfish meat is popular in Japanese restaurants and can be substantially cheaper than that of other fish species, leading to some vendors intentionally mislabelling it as Butterfish or Cod, resulting in consumer health issues.
edges.label: importanceToHumans

edges.c: In January 2007, ParknShop, a supermarket chain in Hong Kong, admitted to selling mislabeled Oilfish in their stores. Over 600 people became sick as a result, suffering from stomach pain and diarrhea. A total of 14 complaints were filed against the supermarket chain, leading to an investigation by the Centre for Food Safety. The fish were originally mislabeled in Indonesia, leading to an investigation and allegations of corruption. ParknShop stopped selling the fish, but argued in court that there was no law against the sale of Oilfish. The supermarket would later plead guilty to 9 charges of inappropriate labeling and was fined HK$45,000. As a result of the incident, the Centre for Food Safety in Hong Kong published new guidelines on the proper labeling of Oilfish and Escolar to consumers, preventing mislabeling. The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation in 2007 reported several cases in Canada where mislabelled Oilfish was sold at Chinese supermarkets.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Escolar is an Oilfish relative, also with high concentrations of wax esters and can be similarly mislabeled.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sabellidae is a family of marine polychaete tube worms known for their protruding feathery branchiae. They build tubes out of a tough, parchment-like exudate, strengthened with sand and bits of shell, with the genus Glomerula secreting a tube of calcium carbonate instead. They can be found in subtidal habitats around the world, and their oldest fossils are known from the Early Jurassic.

edges.c: Salps are common in equatorial, temperate, and cold seas, including the Southern Ocean near Antarctica. They can be found singly at the surface or in long colonies.

edges.c: Salps have a complex life cycle, involving alternating generations of solitary individuals and aggregate chains. They reproduce asexually and sexually, and their rapid reproduction leads to short-lived blooms.

edges.c: Salps play a significant role in responding to phytoplankton blooms, and their abundance can impact the ocean's carbon cycle. They also affect other planktonic species and can contribute to the ocean's biological pump.
edges.label: oceanographicImportance

edges.c: Despite their jellyfish-like appearance, salps are chordates with dorsal nerve cords, related to vertebrates.

nodes: Reynolds, P. D. (2002). "The scaphopoda". Molluscan Radiation - Lesser-known Branches. Advances in Marine Biology.
Scarabino V. (1995). Scaphopoda of the tropical Pacific and Indian Oceans, with description of 3 new genera and 42 new species
Steiner, G.; Kabat, A. R. (2001). Catalogue of supraspecific taxa of Scaphopoda (Mollusca). Zoosystema.

edges.c: Tusk shells are a class of shelled marine mollusks with a worldwide distribution. They are the only class of exclusively infaunal marine mollusks, living in soft substrates offshore. The shells of species within this class range in length from 0.5 to 18 cm and are not as easily visible in beach drift as the shells of sea snails and clams. Molecular data suggest they are a sister group to cephalopods.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The morphological shape of the scaphopod body makes it difficult to orient satisfactorily, leading to disagreements among researchers. The apex of the shell and mantle are anatomically dorsal, and the large aperture is ventral and anterior. Functionally, the large aperture with the foot is anterior, the apical area posterior, the concave side dorsal, and the convex side ventral.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Members of the order Dentaliida have glassy-smooth and narrow shells, while the Dentalids tend to have strongly ribbed and rough shells. Their shell structures allow them to move with surprising speed through loose sediment.
edges.label: description

edges.c: When Dentalids sense vibrations, their defensive response is to freeze, making them harder to detect by predators.
edges.label: defense

edges.c: The mantle of a scaphopod is entirely within the shell. The foot extends from the larger end of the shell and is used to burrow through the substrate. Most adult scaphopods live entirely buried within the substrate, with water entering the mantle cavity through the apical aperture.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Scaphopods have minute tentacles around the foot, called captacula, which sift through sediment and convey food to the mouth. The mouth has a grinding radula for digestion, and the digestive system includes a digestive diverticulum, esophagus, stomach, and intestine. They lack gills and have a unique feeding mechanism.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The scaphopod vascular system is rudimentary, lacking a heart and ctenidia. Metabolic waste is excreted through a pair of nephridia close to the anus. They have unique openings that may serve to relieve internal pressure by ejecting body fluid.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The nervous system is generally similar to that of cephalopods, with cerebral and pleural ganglia. Scaphopods have no eyes, osphradia, or distinct sensory organs, but possess genes involved in photoreceptor formation and function.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Scaphopods have separate sexes and external fertilization. Once fertilized, the eggs hatch into a free-living trochophore larva, which develops into a veliger larva that closely resembles the adult. They remain univalved throughout their morphogenesis.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Tusk shells live in seafloor sediment, feeding primarily on foraminiferans and sometimes supplementing this with vegetable matter.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The group is composed of two subtaxa, Dentaliida and Gadilida, each consisting of several families and genera. The differences between the two orders hinge on size and details of their anatomy.
edges.label: description

edges.c: There is a good fossil record of scaphopods from the Mississippian onwards, making them the youngest molluscan class. Their evolutionary relationships and phylogeny with other molluscan groups remain contentious.
edges.label: fossilRecord

edges.c: The shells of some tusk shell species were used as shell money by native populations in the Pacific Northwest and for crafting belts and headdresses by the Natufian culture of the Middle East.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Individual animals known as polyps have a cylindrical body crowned by an oral disc surrounded by a ring of tentacles. The base of the polyp secretes the stony material from which the coral skeleton is formed.

edges.c: Secreted by the epidermis of the lower part of the body, the skeleton initially forms a cup surrounding the polyp. It contains radially aligned plates called septa.

edges.c: Sclerasterias is a genus of starfish in the family Asteriidae. Adult individuals have five arms but small, immature individuals have six. Young individuals, called Hydrasterias, often undergo fissiparity where the disc splits into two parts, each bearing three arms, and new arms develop on each part to complete the complement of arms. This may be an adaptation to life in cold, deep seas where most of the species are found.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Scorpaenidae is a family of mostly marine fish known for their venomous species and characterized by sharp spines coated with venomous mucus. It includes hundreds of members and is widespread in tropical and temperate seas, primarily found in the Indo-Pacific. The family was described by the French naturalist Antoine Risso in 1826.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The Scorpaeniformes is a diverse order of ray-finned fish, including the lionfishes and sculpins. It is one of the five largest orders of bony fishes by number of species, with over 1,320. They are known as 'mail-cheeked' fishes due to their distinguishing characteristic, the suborbital stay: a backwards extension of the third circumorbital bone across the cheek to the preoperculum. Scorpaeniform fishes are carnivorous, mostly feeding on crustaceans and smaller fish. They typically have spiny heads, and rounded pectoral and caudal fins.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The suborder Scorpaenoidei is usually found in the benthic zone and includes the groups sea robins and scorpionfishes. The sea robins are further classified into two families: sea robins and armored sea robins. The scorpionfishes have twelve families and are very dynamic in size.
edges.label: description

edges.c: This suborder includes families such as Bembridae, Platycephalidae, and Hoplichthyidae, and is associated with the superfamily Platycephaloidea.
edges.label: description

edges.c: This suborder includes the family Normanichthyidae and is associated with the superfamily Normanichthyoidea.
edges.label: description

edges.label: description

edges.c: This suborder includes families such as Hypoptychidae, Aulorhynchidae, and Gasterosteidae, and is associated with the superfamily Gasterosteoidea.

edges.c: Scotoplanes is a genus of deep-sea sea cucumbers belonging to the family Elpidiidae. Its species are commonly known as sea pigs. These creatures inhabit the deep ocean bottoms, particularly on the abyssal plains in the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans, as well as in the Antarctic.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Scotoplanes move through the top layer of seafloor sediment using their enlarged tube feet. They also have the ability to swim when disturbed. Some species are benthopelagic and spend time in the water column. Their frontal lobe as well as two anal lobes help propel them through the water, and their tentacles aid in detecting their surroundings while moving.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Deep ocean bottoms, specifically on the abyssal plain, at depths of over 1,200 to 5,000 meters.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Scotoplanes are deposit feeders, obtaining food by extracting organic particles from deep-sea mud. They demonstrate strong preferences for rich, organic food that has freshly fallen from the ocean's surface, such as whale corpses.
edges.label: feeding

edges.c: They exhibit behavioral patterns of aggregation, where large numbers will aggregate either to feed or mate. They also host parasitic and commensal organisms, providing shelter to juvenile crabs and other organisms.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: Bilaterally symmetrical with six pairs of tube feet, ten buccal tentacles lining the oral cavity
edges.label: anatomy

edges.c: Their skin contains a toxic chemical called holothurin, and they have external appendages including tube feet, dorsal papillae, and buccal tentacles.
edges.label: defenseMechanism

edges.c: They breathe from their anus, lacking a respiratory tree, and their bodies are not suited for the surface.
edges.label: respiratorySystem

edges.c: They have a unique reproductive system with one gonad in both females and males, and active gametogenesis has been observed in both sexes.
edges.label: reproductiveSystem

edges.c: Consists of a network of nerves without ganglia.
edges.label: nervousSystem

edges.c: Similar to other echinoderms, Scotoplanes have a water vascular system which is responsible for the efficacy of their vascular system.
edges.label: waterVascularSystem

edges.c: The Scyphozoa are an exclusively marine class of the phylum Cnidaria, referred to as the true jellyfish. They have existed from the earliest Cambrian to the present.
edges.label: Description

edges.c: The class name Scyphozoa comes from the Greek word skyphos (σκύφος), denoting a kind of drinking cup and alluding to the cup shape of the organism.
edges.label: origin

edges.c: Most species of Scyphozoa have two life-history phases, including the planktonic medusa or polyp form, and an inconspicuous, but longer-lived, bottom-dwelling polyp.
edges.label: LifeHistoryPhases

edges.c: They typically range from 2 to 40 cm in diameter, with the largest species reaching 2 metres across.
edges.label: Size

edges.c: Scyphomedusae are found throughout the world's oceans, from the surface to great depths; no Scyphozoa occur in freshwater or on land.
edges.label: Habitat

edges.c: As medusae, they eat a variety of crustaceans and fish, which they capture using stinging cells called nematocysts.
edges.label: Feeding

edges.c: Scyphozoans usually display a four-part symmetry and have an internal gelatinous material called mesoglea, which provides structural integrity.
edges.label: Symmetry

edges.c: Scyphozoans have no durable hard parts, including no head, no skeleton, and no specialized organs for respiration or excretion.
edges.label: PhysicalFeatures

edges.c: The jellyfish swims by alternately contracting and relaxing muscle fibres within the mesoglea.
edges.label: Movement

edges.c: The mouth opens into a central stomach, from which interconnected diverticula radiate outwards, and some species have additional, smaller mouths in the oral arms.
edges.label: DigestiveSystem

edges.c: Most species appear to be gonochorists, with separate male and female individuals.
edges.label: SexualDimorphism

edges.c: The fertilized egg produces a planular larva which quickly attaches itself to the sea bottom, and then develops into the hydroid stage of the lifecycle.
edges.label: Development

edges.c: Scyphozoa include jellyfish fished commercially for food, such as the moon jelly Aurelia aurita and the enormous Nemopilema nomurai, which in some years causes major fisheries disruptions.
edges.label: CommercialImportance

edges.c: About 200 extant species are recognized at present, but the true diversity is likely to be at least 400 species.
edges.label: ExtantSpecies

edges.c: The Classification and Distribution of the Class Scyphozoa 'Scyphomedusae'. Encyclopædia Britannica (11th ed.). 1911.
edges.label: Encyclopedia

edges.c: Starfish, also known as sea stars, are marine invertebrates with a star-shaped body and multiple arms radiating from a central disc. They are part of the class Asteroidea and belong to the phylum Echinodermata. There are over 1,900 species of starfish found in all the world's oceans, inhabiting a wide range of habitats from tropical zones to polar regions and depths of up to 6,000 meters.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Most starfish have five arms, although the number can vary. Some species have a larger number of arms, up to 15. The body wall consists of a thin cuticle, an epidermis, a thick dermis, and a coelomic myoepithelial layer. The dermis contains an endoskeleton of calcium carbonate components known as ossicles. Starfish have a hydraulic water vascular system that helps in locomotion, adhesion, food manipulation, and gas exchange.
edges.label: general

edges.c: The water vascular system is a hydraulic system made up of fluid-filled canals and is concerned with functions like locomotion, adhesion, food manipulation, and gas exchange. Water enters the system through the madreporite, a porous sieve-like ossicle, and is linked through a stone canal to a ring canal around the mouth opening. Radial canals lead off from this, and tube feet extend from these canals to assist in movement and feeding.
edges.label: water_vascular_system

edges.c: Starfish are mostly generalist predators, feeding on microalgae, sponges, bivalves, snails, and other small animals. Some species are detritivores or suspension feeders, and a few are able to absorb organic nutrients from the surrounding water. Some starfish species are known to eat coral polyps or are capable of hunting prey much larger than their mouths by using specialized feeding behaviors.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Most starfish are gonochorous, having separate male and female individuals. Some species are simultaneous hermaphrodites, producing eggs and sperm at the same time. Starfish have distinctive reproductive strategies that include free spawning of buoyant eggs and sperm into the water, brooding of eggs, internal fertilization, and asexual reproduction through fission or autotomy of limbs. Larvae of some species can also reproduce asexually.
edges.label: sexual_reproduction

edges.c: Starfish species are found in all of the world's oceans, inhabiting a wide range of marine environments from tropical coral reefs, rocky shores, and tidal pools to kelp forests, seagrass meadows, and the deep-sea floor. The greatest diversity of species occurs in coastal areas.
edges.label: distribution_and_habitat

edges.c: Starfish play important ecological roles as keystone species in marine communities. Their feeding activities can regulate the diversity, distribution, and abundance of microorganisms, and they also have the ability to control populations of certain prey species. However, some starfish outbreaks have caused damage to coral reefs, threatening biodiversity and reef-feeding fish. Invasive starfish species can also negatively impact marine ecosystems by threatening commercially important populations of other marine organisms.
edges.label: impact

edges.c: The fossil record for starfish dates back to the Paleozoic, and there are Lagerstätten, known as 'starfish beds' where accumulations of complete skeletal structures occur. Starfish rapidly diversified during the Early Jurassic period, and phylogenetic data suggests that they may have undergone significant speciation over the past 6,000 years. The order and phylogeny of the Asteroidea has been challenging to resolve, with molecular evidence leading to ongoing debates about the taxonomic classification of the group.
edges.label: fossil_record

edges.c: Starfish are used in reproductive and developmental studies, as well as regenerative and cloning research due to their unique ability to regenerate lost body parts and expel foreign objects from their bodies. Their large oocytes make them well suited for laboratory studies.
edges.label: research

edges.c: Starfish have been featured in various legends, fables, and cultural references, appearing in myths and fables from different cultures including an aboriginal Australian fable and ancient Hawaiian prayers. Starfish have also been used as titles for novels, non-fiction books, and business management concepts. In popular culture, starfish have been portrayed in TV series and popular animation.
edges.label: legend_and_culture

edges.c: While occasionally used as food in some cultures, starfish are not commonly consumed due to the presence of unpleasant-tasting compounds, toxins, and the risk of transmitting paralytic shellfish poisoning. They are sometimes taken from their habitat and sold as souvenirs, curios, or for display in aquariums.
edges.label: food

edges.c: Starfish has been chosen as a name for military vessels, night-time decoy sites during World War II, and high-altitude nuclear tests. The name is also used for computer networks, software tools, and a seabed imaging system and company.
edges.label: military_history

edges.c: The copper rockfish, Sebastes caurinus, is a highly variable marine ray-finned fish with coloration ranging from dark reddish brown to lighter pinkish brown. It is a demersal fish found in the eastern Pacific, creating and communicating with sound for agonistic behaviors.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The copper rockfish is widespread and found in rocky areas with high relief in the Pacific coast from the Gulf of Alaska to the Pacific side of the Baja California peninsula. It occurs at depths of about 10 to 183 metres (33 to 600 ft).
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The copper rockfish has a wide distribution from the northern reaches of the Gulf of Alaska to north of Guerrero Negro, Baja California, and is found at a wide range of depths in the Pacific.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Copper rockfish are viviparous, reaching sexual maturity between three and eight years. Females bear more young when they are larger. They have a gestation period of around 10 months and can live over forty years.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Juveniles feed primarily on planktonic crustaceans and as they grow, they feed on larger crustaceans, squid, octopus, and smaller fish. They are preyed on by lingcod, cabezone, salmon, sea birds, sea mammals, and humans.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Copper rockfish are faithful to their chosen home, traveling no more than a mile from their location. Separate populations differ significantly from each other due to limited larva dispersal distance and habitat patchiness.
edges.label: behavior

edges.c: The copper rockfish is an important component in commercial fisheries in western Mexico and is fished for by recreational anglers in California. However, it has been classified as a Species of Greatest Conservation Need in Washington and the recreational fishery in Puget Sound has been closed.
edges.label: conservationStatus

edges.c: The canary rockfish is a marine ray-finned fish native to the waters of the Pacific Ocean off western North America. It is notable for its orange-yellow appearance with a blotchy orange pattern over a whitish or light gray background. It has three stripes on the head angling downwards and back, and its fins are orange, with the pectoral, pelvic, and anal fins somewhat pointed and larger. Some individuals have dark blotches on the body or dorsal fin.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Young canaries live in relatively shallow water, moving to deeper water as they mature. Adults are mostly found at depths of 80–200 meters, tending to collect in groups around pinnacles and similar high-relief rock formations, especially where the current is strong.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: Juveniles feed on small crustacea such as krill larvae, copepods, and amphipods, while adults eat krill and small fishes.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: The population of canary rockfish on the U.S. West Coast was declared overfished in 2000, leading to a recovery plan being implemented in 2001. This stock was declared rebuilt in 2015. While a distinct population segment (DPS) of canary rockfish in Puget Sound was proposed for listing as threatened under the Endangered Species Act, it was later removed from the Federal List of Threatened and Endangered Species due to new genetic information indicating lack of discreteness.
edges.label: conservationStatus

edges.c: The yelloweye rockfish is a marine fish known for its coloring, long lifespan, and slow reproductive age. It is prized for its meat and is found in the East Pacific, ranging from Baja California to Dutch Harbor in Alaska. The species was declared overfished in 2002 and its population has been in decline.

edges.c: The Serpulidae are a family of sessile, tube-building annelid worms in the class Polychaeta. They secrete tubes of calcium carbonate and have a specialized operculum that blocks the entrance of their tubes when they withdraw into them. They are important biomineralizers among annelids, with about 300 known species, most of which live in saline waters. The earliest serpulids are known from the Permian period.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The blood of most species contains the oxygen-binding pigment chlorocruorin, which is used to transport oxygen to the tissues and has a strong affinity for carbon monoxide.
edges.label: blood_pigment

edges.c: Empty serpulid shells can sometimes be confused with the shells of worm snails, with a noticeable difference being that serpulid shells are dull inside, whereas the molluscan vermetid shells are shiny inside.
edges.label: confusion_with_snails

edges.c: Solanderia is the sole genus of hydrozoans in the monotypic family Solanderiidae. They form large colonies and are one of about 1000 species of athecate hydroids, which do not construct a skeletal covering for their polyps.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Chitinous skeleton is internal, branches, and may form anastomoses. The skeleton is formed by coalescence and modification of adjacent hydrocauline tubes. The coenosarc covers the entire colony and penetrates skeletal interstices. The hydranths cover the whole colony surface and are uniform in structure, cylindrical, with a single whorl of capitate tentacles around the mouth. Numerous similar tentacles are scattered over the body.
edges.label: skeleton

edges.c: Solanderia is known from its polyp or hydroid stage, and produces gonophores which release sperm and eggs for reproduction. Where known, the gonophores are cryptomedusoid or eumedusoid, arising directly from the coenosarc.
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Species of Solanderia are eaten by nudibranchs in the genus Hermosita and the family Pleurolidiidae.
edges.label: ecology

edges.c: The Solasteridae is a family of sea stars.

edges.c: Solemyidae is a family of saltwater clams, marine protobranch bivalve mollusks known for their symbiotic relationship with sulfur-oxidizing bacteria.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Solemyids have a small or non-existent digestive tract and feeding appendages that are too short to reach outside the shell. They host sulfur-oxidizing bacteria intracellularly within their gill filaments and rely on them as the primary source of nutrition.
edges.label: characteristics

edges.c: Solemyids have a symbiotic relationship with sulfur-oxidizing bacteria, where the bacteria provide organic matter through chemoautotrophy, and the clam provides a habitat with necessary substrates for the bacteria.
edges.label: symbiotic_relationship

edges.c: Solmaris is a genus of diminutive hydrozoans.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Members of this family have dome-shaped bells and numerous tentacles set above the undulating margin of the bell. They do not have gastric pouches as do other members of the order. The gonads are situated inside the wall of the stomach.
edges.label: characteristics

edges.c: Solmissus is a genus of hydrozoans known for actively hunting for prey, rather than passively waiting for plankton to pass by. They are found in the deep waters of Monterey Bay, California, mostly in the deep sea, mid water (700–1,000 m (2,300–3,300 ft)). They can grow to be 20 cm (7.9 in) in diameter and feed on gelatinous zooplankton, including salps and doliolids, ctenophores, jellyfish, and copepods.

edges.c: Stellamedusa is a monotypic genus of jellyfish, with a single recognized species, Stellamedusa ventana. It was first described in the Journal of the Marine Biological Association in 2004 by Kevin Raskoff and George Matsumoto of the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute.

The species name comes from the remotely operated vehicle (ROV) Ventana, a deep-diving robot submarine that first recorded the jelly on video in 1990.

edges.c: Sternoptyx is an oceanic ray-finned fish genus belonging to the family Sternoptychidae. It is the type genus of the Sternoptychidae and the marine hatchetfish subfamily Sternoptychinae. The fish have silvery, high, and laterally compressed bodies and large, non-telescopic eyes. Despite being relatively small, even the largest species do not exceed 60 millimetres (2.4 in) in standard length.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Fossils of this genus show that they have existed at least since the Early Oligocene, about 30 million years ago.
edges.label: existence

edges.c: Sternoptyx diaphana is a short, deep-bodied fish with a laterally compressed body and a maximum length of about 45 mm (1.8 in). The mouth is nearly vertical, the snout is short and the eyes are large. The body slopes steeply up from the head and levels off at the caudal peduncle. In front of the dorsal fin is a toothed, pear-shaped translucent plate supported by a single spine. The dorsal fin has 9 to 12 soft rays and the anal fin 13 to 14. There is a translucent fold of skin just below the short tail, and another below the ventral region of the body. There are photophores behind and below the eye, on the gill cover, and rows of photophores on the underside of the fish. The dorsal region is dark, the flanks are silvery and the fins transparent.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sternoptyx diaphana has a wide distribution in temperate and tropical waters of all the world's oceans, although occurring with less frequency in equatorial seas. Its depth range is 300 and 1,500 metres (1,000 and 5,000 ft), but it is most often found between about 600 and 900 metres (2,000 and 3,000 ft), where the water temperature is between 4 and 11 °C (39 and 52 °F). It appears not to make the daily vertical migrations made by some related species.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The diet consists of small fish, euphausiids, decapods, copepods and amphipods. Larger fish generally consume larger food items; the diet varies with location with the fish appearing to be opportunistic predators of whatever prey species they encounter.
edges.label: ecology

edges.c: Sternoptyx diaphana has a very wide distribution, is a common species and faces no particular threats. The International Union for Conservation of Nature has assessed its conservation status as being of "least concern".
edges.label: status

edges.c: The Stichopodidae are a family of sea cucumbers with large or medium-sized holothuroids having an angular body shape, a flat ventral surface, and large cone-shaped projections. They have 20 peltate tentacles around their mouths and are usually found on soft substrates like sand or rubble.

edges.c: Stylasterias is a genus of starfish in the family Asteriidae. Stylasterias forreri, the velcro star, is the only species in the genus. It is found on the Pacific coast of Canada and the United States.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The velcro star is a large starfish, growing to a maximum diameter of 100 cm (39 in), but is usually considerably smaller. The central disc is small and the five (occasionally six) arms are long and tapering. Rows of large spines run down the arms, each one surrounded by a ring of 30-40 pedicellariae, tiny pincer-like structures. Between the spines are tufts of pale gills. The colour of the velcro star is some shade of grey or black, or occasionally beige.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The velcro star occurs on the Pacific coast of North America, from Kodiak Island, Alaska, to Southern California. It is found at depths to about 530 m (1,740 ft). It is generally uncommon and mostly occurs in deep water at the head of fiords.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The velcro star feeds on invertebrates such as gastropod molluscs and chitons. If anything touches its aboral (upper) surface, the starfish reacts by snapping shut the pedicellariae in the vicinity of the stimulus. The velcro star can also defend itself against attack by predators such as the morning sun star (Solaster dawsoni) by inflicting thousands of nips with its pedicellariae.
edges.label: biology

edges.c: Symphurus thermophilus is a species of tonguefish notable for being the only flatfish known to be an obligate inhabitant of hydrothermal vents. It is known from several widely dispersed locations in the western Pacific Ocean and occurs in great numbers. They are tolerant of harsh conditions and are often found in close association with elemental sulfur, including molten sulfur pools that exceed 180 °C in temperature. As they are not significantly different in appearance and feeding habits from other tonguefishes, they are thought to be relatively recent colonizers of vent ecosystems. These fish were first observed in nature in 1988 and were provisionally assigned to the species Symphurus orientalis before being recognized as a new species. The species name thermophilus is from the Greek thermos meaning "heat" and philos meaning "lover," referring to its association with hydrothermal vents.

edges.c: The shortdorsal cutthroat eel, also known as the shortfin cut-throat eel, is a marine, deep water-dwelling eel found in the Indo-Pacific and western central Atlantic Ocean. It was described by Albert Günther in 1887. It inhabits the continental slope at a depth range of 900 to 3,000 metres (3,000 to 9,800 ft), with a preference for depths between 1,000 to 2,500 metres (3,300 to 8,200 ft). It belongs to the family Synaphobranchidae (cutthroat eels) and can reach a maximum total length of 111 centimetres (44 in).

edges.c: The Thecosomata, or sea butterflies, are small, pelagic, free-swimming sea snails known as holoplanktonic opisthobranch gastropod mollusks.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Sea butterflies have evolved adaptations for free-floating and swimming in the ocean, including the loss of shells and gills in some families, and the development of wing-like lobes for propulsion.
edges.label: morphology

edges.c: The high flexibility of their 'wings' allows sea butterflies to 'fly' through the water with slow flapping movements.
edges.label: swimming

edges.c: Sea butterflies perform diurnal vertical migration, changing their depth in the water column from day to night.
edges.label: migration

edges.c: Sea butterflies are generally herbivorous, passive plankton-feeders, and employ a peculiar method of ensnaring planktonic food using a mucous web.

edges.c: They undertake regular diel vertical migration through the water column in their pursuit of planktonic prey.

edges.c: Thetys vagina, or the twin sailed salp, is the largest known solitary species of salp and the only valid species of the genus Thetys. It was first described by W.G Tilesius in 1802. The species is transparent and gelatinous, making it difficult to be seen in water, which is helpful in avoiding predators. It has a fossil range that is very recent. Other animals often mistaken for T. vagina are Salpa fusiformis, Aurelia aurita, and Pegea confoederata. There is no known status of conservation for this species. T. vagina DNA was sequenced as part of a larger project in 2014, where spiny lobster larvae were found attached to T. vagina and consuming it.

edges.c: The Clionidae are a family of sea angels, which are a group of pelagic marine gastropods. They resemble angels, complete with flapping 'wings', hence their common name. They are gelatinous, mostly transparent pteropods, and they only have shells in their embryonic stage. They are mostly very small, with the largest species (Clione limacina) reaching 5 cm (2 in).
edges.label: description

edges.c: The Clionidae use winglike flaps for rhythmical locomotion, as if flying in the sea. These 'wings' are attached to the anterior part of the body. The posterior part is gelatinous and mostly transparent. The orange visceral sac is confined to the anterior part.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Mating is carried out ventrally for mutual fertilization. The following spring, this results in a free-floating, gelatinous egg mass.

edges.c: The ICZN has ruled the correct name of gastropod family is Clionidae Gray, 1847, with type genus Clione Pallas, 1774.

edges.c: Torquaratoridae is a family of acorn worms (Hemichordata) that lives in deep waters between 350 and 4000 meters. They use cilia to glide over the ocean floor and feed on detritus, leaving behind a trail of feces.

edges.c: Cutlassfishes are predatory fish in the family Trichiuridae of the order Scombriformes found in seas throughout the world. They are long, slender, and generally steely blue or silver in colour, with reduced or absent pelvic and caudal fins, giving them an eel-like appearance, and large fang-like teeth. Some species are known as scabbardfishes, hairtails, or frostfishes.

edges.c: Turridae is a taxonomic family name for predatory sea snails, marine gastropod mollusks in the superfamily Conoidea. The family is a major component of the Indo-Pacific molluscan fauna, and its species are found worldwide, mostly in the neritic zone. The family was originally thought to consist of several thousand closely related sea snail species, but it was later discovered to be polyphyletic. As a result, the family has been greatly reduced in size, and a number of other families were created to contain monophyletic lineages previously thought to be part of Turridae.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Species in the family Turridae are found worldwide, with most of them located in the neritic zone. The family is a major component of the Indo-Pacific molluscan fauna.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: The shells of Turridae species are narrow with a more or less fusiform shape. The whorls are elongate to broadly spindle-shaped and conical. They are generally small, usually less than 15 mm in length, with strong ribs and spiral ridges. The aperture is long and narrow, with a siphonal canal and an anal sinus. The shells show variable sculpture and are generally carnivorous, predatory gastropods with a poison gland and toxoglossan radula used for predation and self-defense.
edges.label: shellDescription

edges.c: The family Turridae was initially considered one of the most difficult groups to study due to a large number of supra-specific described taxa, species diversity, and rarity. The taxonomy of Turridae has undergone several revisions over the years, resulting in the creation of new subfamilies and the resolution of the polyphyletic family into 13 monophyletic families based on anatomical and molecular phylogeny.
edges.label: taxonomyHistory

edges.c: The common murre is a large auk with a circumpolar distribution, occurring in low-Arctic and boreal waters in the North Atlantic and North Pacific. It spends most of its time at sea, only coming to land to breed on rocky cliff shores or islands.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Breeding habitat includes islands, rocky shores, cliffs, and sea stacks. The population is large, with possibly 7.3 million breeding pairs or 18 million individuals.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The common murre has a circumpolar distribution, occurring in low-Arctic and boreal waters in the North Atlantic and North Pacific. Some populations have short migration distances, instead remaining close to the breeding site year-round.
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Flies with fast wing beats at a speed of 80 km/h (50 mph). Groups of birds are often seen flying together in a line just above the sea surface.
edges.label: characteristics

edges.c: Pursuit-diver that forages for food by swimming underwater using its wings for propulsion. Dives usually last less than one minute, but the bird can swim underwater for distances of over 30 m (100 ft) and has been recorded diving to depths of up to 180 m (590 ft).
edges.label: method

edges.c: Eats small schooling forage fish, marine worms, squid, and crustaceans such as amphipods. Consumes 20–32 g of food in a day on average.
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Can venture far from its breeding grounds to forage; distances of 100 km (60 mi) and more are often observed.
edges.label: foraging range

edges.c: Nests in densely packed colonies in areas such as islands, rocky shores, cliffs, and sea stacks. Does not make nests and lays its eggs on bare rock ledges or the ground.
edges.label: reproductiveSystem

edges.c: Both parents incubate the egg for 28 to 34 days in shifts of 1–38 hours.
edges.label: incubation

edges.c: Chicks leave the nest after 16 to 30 days (average 20–22 days), and glide down into the sea, slowing their fall by fluttering as they are not yet able to fly. The male cares for the chick at sea until it is able to fly.
edges.label: growthOfChick

edges.c: Major oil spills double the winter mortality of breeding adults but appear to have little effect on birds less than three years old. This loss of breeding birds can be compensated by increased recruitment of 4–6 year olds to breeding colonies.
edges.label: pollution

edges.c: In areas such as Newfoundland and Labrador, the birds, along with the related thick-billed murre, are consumed.
edges.label: foodSource

edges.c: Urticina is a genus of relatively large and often colorful sea anemones in the family Actiniidae from the North Pacific, North Atlantic, and Arctic Oceans.
edges.label: description

nodes: SeaLife: A Complete Guide to the Marine Environment

edges.c: The Valvatida is an order of starfish in the class Asteroidea, containing 695 species in 172 genera in 17 families. The order encompasses both tiny species, like those in the genus Asterina, and species reaching up to 75 cm, such as those in the genus Thromidia. Most species in this order have five arms with tube feet and are primarily identified by the presence of conspicuous marginal ossicles.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The vampire squid is a small cephalopod found in extreme deep sea conditions. It has two long retractile filaments that distinguish it from both octopuses and squids. It is the only known surviving member of its order, Vampyromorphida.

edges.c: Venefica tentaculata is a marine, subtropical eel known for its wide distribution in the eastern central and northwestern Pacific Ocean, including Mexico, Nicaragua, Japan, and the United States. It dwells at a depth range of 100 to 500 metres (330 to 1,640 ft) and may dive even deeper. Males can reach a maximum total length of 90 centimetres (35 in).
