edges.c: Xenophyophorea is a clade of multinucleate unicellular organisms found on the ocean floor, belonging to the group of foraminiferans. They form an exoskeleton known as a test and are abundant in the world's oceans, at depths of 500 to 10,600 metres.
edges.label: description

edges.c: The name Xenophyophora means 'bearer of foreign bodies', referring to the sediments called xenophyae, which are cemented together to construct their tests. It was initially classified as primitive Foraminifera and later considered an independent class of Rhizopoda and a new eukaryotic phylum of Protista.
edges.label: meaning

edges.c: Agglutinated tests made of calcium carbonate and other foreign mineral particles glued together with organic cements, ranging from a few millimetres to 20 centimetres in diameter
edges.label: composition

edges.c: Delicate and elaborate shapes, including compartmentalized tests consisting of multiple chambers
edges.label: variation

edges.c: Pellets bundled together in long strings
edges.label: stercomares

edges.c: Crystals of barite found within their cytoplasm
edges.label: granellae

edges.c: Threadlike structures found outside of the granellare in some xenophyophores
edges.label: linellae

edges.c: Agglutinated particles from which the test is constructed, containing sediment particles, sponge spicules, radiolarian tests, and the tests of smaller foraminifera
edges.label: xenophyae

edges.c: Select certain minerals and elements from their environment that are included in their tests and cytoplasm or concentrated in excretions
edges.label: mineral_selection

edges.c: Assumed to involve an alternation of generations
edges.label: reproduction

edges.c: Form in a specialized part of the granellare, with subsequent stages resembling amoeba-like structures
edges.label: gametes

edges.c: Found between depths of 500 and 10,600 metres, with most being epifaunal living atop the seabed, while one species is known to be infaunal burying itself up to 6 centimetres deep into the sediment
edges.label: depth

edges.c: Found in all four major ocean basins and in areas of enhanced organic carbon flux such as beneath productive surface waters, sub-marine canyons, seamounts, abyssal hills, and continental slopes
edges.label: distribution

edges.c: Actively uptake food from surrounding sediments using pseudopodia and use the test to trap particles
edges.label: diet

edges.c: Play a major role in ocean-floor biogeochemical cycling, supplement their feeding with bacteria growing on their waste products, and may utilize diatoms and dissolved organic matter
edges.label: feeding_ecology

edges.c: No positively-identified xenophyophore fossils have been discovered yet
edges.label: fossils

edges.c: Some ediacaran fossils have been suggested to represent fossil xenophyophores, but no conclusive evidence has been found
edges.label: possible_links

edges.c: Important in deep sea-floor ecosystems, serving as 'ecosystem engineers' and providing habitat, with local population densities as high as 2,000 individuals per 100 square metres
edges.label: role

edges.c: Host and attract a variety of organisms, serving as nurseries for fish and providing food for other species
edges.label: interactions

edges.c: The California sea lion (Zalophus californianus) is a coastal eared seal native to western North America. It is one of six species of sea lions. Its natural habitat ranges from southeast Alaska to central Mexico, including the Gulf of California.

edges.c: The eelpouts are a ray-finned fish family characterized by their eel-like appearance. They are predominantly found in the Northern Hemisphere and are mostly marine, dwelling at varying depths.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Eelpouts are predominantly found in the arctic, north pacific, and north Atlantic oceans but species are also found around the globe.
edges.label: habitat

edges.c: The largest member of the family is Zoarces americanus, which may reach 1.1 m in length.
edges.label: size

edges.c: The spelling was changed to Zoarcidae after the spelling of the genus Zoarces was corrected by Theodore Gill in 1861.
edges.label: spellingChange

edges.c: 5th edition of Fishes of the World classifies this family within the suborder Zoarcoidei, within the order Scorpaeniformes.
edges.label: classification

edges.c: Other authorities classify this family in the infraorder Zoarcales within the suborder Cottoidei of the Perciformes.
edges.label: otherAuthorities

edges.c: Continuous dorsal and anal fins down their bodies up to their caudal fin
edges.label: fins

edges.c: Produce the pigment biliverdin, which turns their bones green
edges.label: pigment

edges.c: Little is known about eelpout populations due to difficulty in sampling and inaccessibly deep habitats
edges.label: populations

edges.c: At least one species has adapted to be able to breathe air when out of water

edges.c: Decapoda is an order of crustaceans within the class Malacostraca, and includes crabs, lobsters, crayfish, shrimp, and prawns. It is estimated to contain nearly 15,000 extant species in around 2,700 genera, with around 3,300 fossil species. Decapods are characterized by having ten legs and a variety of appendages for feeding and movement.

edges.c: The family Munididae is taxonomically separated from the family Galatheidae. It includes squat lobsters, which can be distinguished by the presence of a trispinose frontal edge to the carapace, a central rostrum, and two spines extending forward from above the eyes. Most species are deep-water taxa.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Some species enter shallow water, but the majority are deep-water taxa, in contrast to the mostly shallow-water Galatheidae.
edges.label: ecology

edges.c: Many genera included in the family Munididae were previously part of the wider circumscription of the family Galatheidae.

edges.c: Mytilidae is a family of small to large marine and brackish-water bivalve molluscs found worldwide, with some species inhabiting freshwater environments. They are known for forming uninterrupted beds on rocky shores and are more abundant in colder seas. This family includes the well-known edible sea mussels and exhibits asymmetrical shells with a thick, adherent periostracum. They attach themselves to solid substrates using a byssus.
edges.label: description

nodes: The Adventures of a Flapjack Octopus

edges.c: Opisthoteuthis californiana, also known as the flapjack octopus, or flapjack devilfish, is a species of umbrella octopus. It usually appears pinkish with fins above its eyes and has a maximum size of 20 cm mantle length. Unlike other octopus species, it is unable to camouflage by changing skin color and texture due to its gelatinous body.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Paragorgia arborea is a species of coral in the family Paragorgiidae, commonly known as the bubblegum coral because of its bulbous branch tips. It mainly grows in depths between 200 and 1,300 metres at temperatures between 3 and 8 °C. It is found widespread in the Northern Atlantic Ocean and Northern Pacific Ocean on seamounts and knolls, and was first described by the Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus in 1758. P. arborea is a foundation species, providing a habitat for other species in deep sea coral ecosystems.
edges.label: description

edges.c: Branching, fan-shaped structure with a tough central trunk and many branches
edges.label: structure

edges.c: P. arborea is hypothesized to be a brooder, where fertilization takes place on or inside the female colony. Corals reproduce sexually by either spawning or brooding, but then once settled, corals reproduce asexually to grow into a many branched colony.
edges.label: reproductiveStrategy

edges.c: P. arborea is a filter feeder that optimizes nutrient uptake by adjusting its behavior to the tidal cycle. It extends its polyps to actively feed when tidal currents bring in organic matter and retract them to digest the food or be inactive afterward.
edges.label: feedingStrategy
